Another green bond market workshop was jointly conducted by CBI with Syntao Green Finance, Lianhe Equator, and ICMA as part of the China SIF week in Beijing in December 2019. The workshop targeted Chinese green bond issuers and potential issuers, green finance advisors, green bond verifiers, and potential investors. The event was attended by approximately 60 participants from the industry (25 female). The topic of the workshop was green bond market development and innovation. 
This green bond market workshop helped to further stimulate the market enthusiasm in green bond issuance and helped revitalize the conversation around green finance in China with innovative practices and latest updates from the market.
Q2 2020
Due to COVID-19 outbreak, and the impossibility to continue with on-site trainings, the project conducted an online webinar on the 28th of May 2020, together with CCX and a few Jiangshu-based green bond issuers/underwriters in China. No information about the number of attendees was provided.
Result_Title: Capacity building and market education workshops for five or six cities in China

Project: Promoting forest protection and peace-building through community-based ecotourism
Description:
Formal training of community ecotourism providers has taken place virtually in the three regions of interest to a different extent. In Serranía de las Quinchas, three capacity building modules were delivered.  First, an ‘ethnobotanical characterization’ training was delivered through a WhatsApp group created for this purpose, with a participation of 48 community members (24 female). In this training, the community learnt about the importance of ethnobotany and its relationship with tourism, the different uses of local plants and their potential contribution to the territory, and the wealth of biodiversity in the territory. The project also delivered a podcast on ‘touristic routes and the integration of the value chain’, with a participation of 26 people (16 female). In this training, the community learnt how to completely develop a comprehensive tourism proposal. Finally, an ‘introduction to community agreements’ was made to 27 people (20 female), where the community learnt about COVID-19, its relation to biodiversity loss, the challenges and opportunities for ecotourism products, and the importance of community agreements in this context. In Bocas del Atrato, the podcast on ‘touristic routes and the integration of the value chain’ was shared with the community. Moreover, an expert on biodiversity helped facilitate two other trainings: an introduction to community agreements with a participation of 14 people (11 female), and a training on ‘tourism and market niches’ 14 attendees (11 female). Through the latter, the community learnt about the characteristics of community tourism, the profile of nature tourists, and bird watching. Finally, in Serranía del Perijá, the project first delivered the ‘ethnobotanical characterization’ training to 20 attendees (6 female). The project also delivered the podcast on ‘touristic routes and the integration of the value chain’ to 18 community members (5 female). The ‘introduction to community agreements’ was attended by 25 people (7 female). 
For more detail on the training courses please enter to https://formacion.e3asesorias.com/
Result_Title: Formal training of community ecotourism providers

Project: Building a sustainable and scalable low carbon future in Mexico​
Description: On February 7th, 2020, CBI organized a workshop on Green Bonds together with the Consejo Consultivo de Finanzas Verdes (CCFV), addressed to Bolsa Mexicana de Valores (BMV)’s internal staff. The workshop had a duration of half a day and was delivered to a total of 23 people (9 female), mainly sales people at BMV.
Result_Title: Additional workshop to Bolsa Mexicana de Valores

Project: China Skill Share: Training to enhance understanding of domestic and global green finance development and Shenzhen's newly-issued Green Finance Regulation (CN-001a-R)
Description:
On 25th and 26th March 2021, Shenzhen held green finance training for financial institutes and regulators registered in the Shenzhen economic zone. This was a one and half day event supported by Shenzhen Local Financial and Supervisory Management Bureau and the People’s Bank of China Shenzhen Centre Branch. The training was to help their financial institutions to better understand the newly launched "Shenzhen Special Economic Zone Green Finance Regulations" and the necessary implementation measures. The aim of the event was to help enhance awareness and knowledge, and learn from international best practice. As such, our experts (Joss Blamire and Rachel Brisley) each developed and pre-recorded a 45-minute presentation on one of the key themes at the event (both presented on 25th March). 

Rachel presented on climate risk assessment and stress testing for the financial service sector in Shenzhen. She considered Shenzhen’s changing climate, impacts for financial institutions and other businesses, global trends and best practices on stress testing and climate risk assessment methodology. Joss presented on TCFD, a framework to help companies report on exposure to climate-related risks and opportunities. He provided a high level introduction to TCFD, best practice for disclosures to make in a report, and a roadmap to work towards producing a report. He explained what the TCFD recommendations are and why they are adopted worldwide. Both experts used relevant case studies to help illustrate their content.

The event was supported by Shenzhen Local Financial and Supervisory Management Bureau and People’s Bank of China Shenzhen Centre Branch. 97 financial institutions (with over 100 audience members) attended the training event, as well as Shenzhen financial regulators. We received feedback forms from 28 attendees (which have been attached/manually uploaded). This low number was likely due to the language challenge (the feedback forms were only in English). Other attendees may not have wanted to complete the forms.
Result_Title: Green finance development and regulatory training sessions (TCFD) with senior officials from Shenzhen government and financial institutions

Project: Climate Transition Pathways
Description: NBI conducted a series of workshops involving the project steering committee and advisory boards from Q3 and Q4 2020 with the aim of producing a multi-stakeholder engagement report. The report summaries stakeholders which NBI engaged with on the project in the business sector, with government, labour and civil society and outlines COP26 communication opportunities. These workshops consisted of three to six-hour hour long online workshops held via MS Teams. To date there have been 4 advisory meetings which took place on 11th September 2020, 9th October 2020, 19th November 2020, and 27th November 2020. These advisory board discussions were with members from industry, government, labour, and civil society from the following organisations: BCG, Congress of South African Trade Unions, The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, Department of Environmental Affairs, Forestry and Fisheries, Just Share, Minerals Council, NBI, Navitas Holdings Proprietary Limited, TIPS, University of Cape Town and WFF. The purpose of these meetings was to discuss climate change in the South African context, provide an overview of the project, status update, content development approach and governance structure, share an overview of analysis and findings in the electricity sector, energy modelling approach, last mile decarbonization, green H2- the opportunity is real, emerging view on just transition for coal, recap of project timelines and engagement, and petrochemical decarbonization pathway and outlook for the rest of the year and 2021. The first advisory meeting was attended by 8 females and 12 males; second advisory meeting was attended by 8 females and 13 males; third advisory meeting was attended by 8 females and 12 males and fourth advisory meeting was attended by 9 females and 15 males.NBI held a total of 4 steering committee meetings which took place on 14th September 2020, 02nd October 2020, 11 November 2020 and 30 Novermber 2020. The steering committee consisted of individuals from the following organisations: Anglo American, BCG, BUSA, Engen, Eskom, Exxaro, FirstRand, JSE, Knowledge Pele, NBI, Sasol, The Banking Association of South Africa, Transnet, Glencore FerroAlloys, Harmony Gold, Minerals Council, NBI, Sibanye StillWater. The following agenda topics were covered in these meetings: :steering committee introductions, recap – project context and status update, content development approach, overview of governance structure, : presentation the overview of findings and analysis on the electricity sector, group discussion on the RE archetype as point for net-zero pathway development and green H2, discussion on Just Transition challenges in mining and recap of project timelines and engagement plan, key objectives and status update, overview of CEO meeting content, key findings on power sector modelling , the Just Transition as a key to enable to transformation, role of gas. The first meeting was attended by 11 males and 10 females, the second meeting was attended by 9 females and 12 males, the third meeting was attended by 18 females and 20 males, and the fourth meeting was 15 females and 9 males.
Result_Title: Technical Advisory Meetings with Government, CSO, and Labour Union stakeholders.

Project: Supporting Mexico’s Green Finance Hub​
Description: Between June 30th and July 4th, 2019, a mission to London to attend the Green Finance Summit organized by the Green Finance Initiative was undertaken. This event provided training on the latest in green financial policy trends, market developments and thought leadership. Most attendees were industry experts, policymakers, and some leading voices in green finance in the country.
Result_Title: Three day mission to London to meet the British institutional investors community

Project: Malaysia outward skillshare: Developing a Climate Change Act and Climate change centre
Description:
Using insights from the workshops and other scoping work, two reports were produced: 
One on the Climate Change Act/climate legislation – this contained recommendations that had already been suggested before the skill-share, but not many inputs were incorporated during the visit itself. 
One on the Climate Change Centre – this did contain some recommendations that were somewhat relevant to the conversations which occurred during the skill-share.
Result_Title: Study recommending how Malaysia could implement its own climate change legislation and CCC

Project: Malaysia outward skillshare: Developing a Climate Change Act and Climate change centre
Description:
Workshop on the UK Climate Change Act and Committee on Climate Change.
Overview of CCA and CCC provided by experts involved in skill share to Malaysian representatives, including Dr Nagulendran (MESTECC Deputy Secretary General) and Mr Jayasignham Raju (MESTECC climate change officer).
Result_Title: Workshop on the UK Climate Change Act and Committe on Climate Change

Project: Malaysia outward skillshare: Developing a Climate Change Act and Climate change centre
Description: The skills and knowledge enhanced through the skill-share validated the need for a Climate Change Centre. Dr Nagu, Deputy Secretary General of the Ministry of Energy, Science, Technology, Environment and Climate Change (MESTECC) commented that the recommendation reports from the mission had become the basis to justify the decision to transition the Malaysian Green Technology Corporation (MGTC) into a CCC.  It is important to note here that the skill share did not lead to the decision to have an equivalent of CCC, which had already been decided, but it provided evidence in supporting this move. However, since the announcement of the transition there has been no evidence that MGTC has been able to function as a CCC as it had originally been intended.
Result_Title: Malaysian stakeholders buy-in to the recommendation set out in the scoping study
indicator: Int. Out 2. 'Adoption of recommendation for policy/legislation'

Project: Strengthening the Legislative-Executive-Stakeholder dialogue on Mexico's climate change and energy goals
Description: The official presentation of the updated proposal for the LMACCDS in August 2020 was followed by a ruling process in Mexico City’s Congress and triggered several months of discussions, in which POLEA was able to participate.
Result_Title: Adoption of the proposal to update Mexico City’s Law on Climate Change Adaptation, Mitigation and Sustainable Development
indicator: Int. Out 2. 'Adoption of recommendation for policy/legislation'

Project: Strengthening the Legislative-Executive-Stakeholder dialogue on Mexico's climate change and energy goals
Description:
Q2 2020
During the second quarter of 2020, Polea signed a collaboration agreement with the Preservation of the Environment, Climate Change and Ecological and Animal Protection Commission (PECCEAPC) of Mexico City’s Congress, through which Polea committed to the delivery of a proposal for the update of Mexico City’s Law on Climate Change Adaptation, Mitigation and Sustainable Development (LMACCDS).
To inform the process, Polea developed a participative approach, conducting consultations with a wide range of stakeholders. In particular, the project deployed an online questionnaire to collect the views of 96 stakeholders on the matter. Moreover, 26 in-depth interviews were conducted with experts and key informants from different sectors. The project also held consultation meetings with high level officers from SEDEMA and five legislators from different political parties. The participative process also included the delivery of two webinars to almost 150 participants, which included interested local legislators, government representatives, and thematic specialists. All the collected evidence was analysed and put together on an executive study which summarised key findings of this participative process. 
Q3 2020
The extraordinary session of the PECCEAPC of Mexico City’s Congress took place on Monday August 3rd, 2020, and POLEA officially presented the updated proposal for the Law on Mitigation and Adaptation to Climate Change and Sustainable Development for Mexico City.
Result_Title: Document with legal proposals and analysis to update Mexico City’s Law on Climate Change Adaptation, Mitigation and Sustainable Development (LMACCDS)

Project: Strengthening the Legislative-Executive-Stakeholder dialogue on Mexico's climate change and energy goals
Description: The updated LMACCDS was approved by the Congress on May 25th, and it came into force on June 10th, 2021. The new legislation is designed to be Paris Agreement compliant, and it includes a legally binding commitment to reach Net Zero by 2050. The country’s capital, home to over 9 million people (and 21 million in the broader metropolitan area), becomes the first subnational entity in the country to commit to carbon neutrality in Mexico, highlighting the significant opportunity to accelerate climate action at the sub national level.
Result_Title: Update of Mexico City’s Law on Climate Change Adaptation, Mitigation and Sustainable Development

Project: Promoting green recovery by championing the power of disclosure, transparency and UK-China collaboration
Description:
CDP has responded to policy consultations and arranged three meetings in Q1 with staff of CSRC, MEE and SEE:
1.	CDP submitted a response to the public consultation on the Guidelines for Investor Relations Management of Listed Companies of China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) on March 5th, 2021, and organised a discussion with the Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE) to collect further suggestions.
2.	CDP met an analyst of the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) on 18 March 2021 to learn updated status of upcoming disclosure regulations. The analyst is in charge of drafting disclosure regulations which is expected to be released in 2021/2022. Following the meeting, CDP provided its Climate Change indicators and Prototype climate-related financial disclosure standard to support CSRC’s research.
3.	CDP had a catch up meeting with the Chinese Academy of Environmental Planning (CAPE), an Institute of the Ministry of Ecology and Environment (MEE) on 23 March  2021. Following this meeting, CDP provided its Climate Change indicators to support CAPE’s research on law-based environmental information disclosure. CAPE will be influential in recommending/advising the types of indicators that will be adopted by CSRC new regulatory framework.
Result_Title: Quarterly meetings of national policy makers from MEE and CSRC

Project: Operationalising Energy Performance Certificates in South Africa
Description: The final report (titled NBEPR User needs, functionality and technical outline, data management and governance policies report) firstly identifies the key user needs that the NBEPR must serve. This is done by both extracting the key relative findings from the previous report (Report of investigation into international EPC best practice to address opportunities and barriers for the local EPC mechanism) and by building on these through interviews with local EPC mechanism actors and additional desktop research. The report then identifies they key functional and non-functional specifications to which the NBEPR must be built in order to meet these user needs. While these are dealt with at a high level in the main body of the report, the appendix provides detailed specifications. These specifications will be translated into technical requirements in the following report (Report of National Building Energy Performance Register (NBEPR) functional and technical specification, and reporting protocols). While this report does not make direct policy recommendations, it provides a basis for ensuring that existing EPC policy is effectively served through the specifications of the NBEPR.
Result_Title: Report of National Building Energy Performance Register (NBEPR)

Project: Expanding the Colombian Climate Asset Disclosure Initiative (CCADI)
Description:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2-2021]
From March through June 2021, two monthly newsletters were sent to CCADI's database of institutional investors and stakeholders with a total of eight (8) newsletters sent. Recipients have been steadily increasing from 143 to 298. Opened newsletters have fluctuated between 30 and 84.
Result_Title: Periodical newsletter to stakeholders

Project: Expanding the Colombian Climate Asset Disclosure Initiative (CCADI)
Description:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2-2021]
The first Podcast Episode of CCADI was published on June 30 2021 in alliance with "Brújula Sonora"   throughout Spotify, Apple, Google, Spreaker, and Podimo. There were also posts on Twitter and LinkedIn promoting the episode. The Episode topic is about the importance of financial decisions for reaching sustainable development. The guests to the podcast were: Daniel Mantilla-García,  Finance Professor from Universidad de los Andes; Ana Fernanda Maiguashca, Ex-codirector of the Banco de la República; Sara Constantino, designer and creator of @laeconstantino.
Result_Title: Podcast episodes in established climate/environmental podcast

Project: Steering the Colombian Road Freight Sector Towards a Zero Emissions Strategy GIRO-ZERO
Description:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2-2021]
During the second quarter, the key progress in the network construction was as follows: 
a) Development of the first Giro Zero Advisory Board on May 13, 2021
b) Development of the first pilot with electric truck with Renting and Expocafe 
c) Building a database with different actors of the public and private sector
Result_Title: GIRO Zero Network established among key stakeholders that could potentially benefit the sector as a whole by easing measurement, reporting, and verification (MRV) of emissions generated within the sector, as well as data sharing among stakeholders

Project: Steering the Colombian Road Freight Sector Towards a Zero Emissions Strategy GIRO-ZERO
Description:
The Industry Review report is divided into different sections in which each refers to best practices in the UK and Latam, state of the art in Colombia, and identifies gaps and to-dos for Colombia in the Road Freight Transport sector
The report identifies sustainable Road Freight Transport KPIs, best practices applied in the industry (e.g. vehicle and alternative fuel technologies, industrial organisation, digitalisation of logistics networks and optimisation, green road infrastructure), and determines the feasibility of their adoption in different segments of the industry.
Also, it identifies risks, barriers, and the latest trends related to the adoption of green practices within the Colombian Road Freight Transport sector and next steps.
The report is written in English (102 pages) along with a summarized report in Spanish. 
This Industry review report was presented to beneficiary institutions such as the Ministry of Transport on 21 June 2021, and COLFECAR on 22 June 2021.
Result_Title: Industry Review Report on the current state of green technologies and practices in the trucking industry in Colombia

Project: Supporting livelihoods through Ecotourism Routes for Forest and Peace.
Description:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT 2021-Q2]:  
From April 21, 2021 to May 3, 2021, Johani Gaviria, a professional tourism guide and ally of Think Tourism, visited the Serranía del Perijá and the Serranía de las Quinchas to do a dry run of the tourism routes designed during UK PACT I. The purpose was to analyse the routes' viability and understand the communities' preparedness and engagement across the tourism supply chain (food, homestays, guidance, transport, etc). 
In Quinchas, with the support of Boyapaz, the routes were operated by different actors in each of the subregions (Altazor, Nazareth, Betania, Camilo, Curubita, Quinchas), who accompanied and guided Johani, provided food and accommodations for his stay. The dry-run was very useful and truly made the community understand the value of their region, biodiversity, and gastronomic knowledge. Tourism resources include natural and landscape resources such as waterfalls, viewpoints, caves, and endemic flora and fauna. It also includes culinary tourism resources, such as "nacuma" or "fruta del pan," a local plant used to produce sweets and fermented beverages. Similarly, there's an agritourism experience in a cocoa farm. Johani empowered them to truly realize that those are the true important attractive selling points of the region. Among the strengths, Johani identified their cultural gastronomy as very unique, using various edible plants of the jungle (although this is not seen in any restaurant in Otanche) to do local, special preparations. 
In Perijá, there are already two tourism operators established which delivered the tourism routes. The first visit was to the mountains near the township Estados Unidos, and the second one to La Victoria, where there are coffee farms and the entry to the mountains. Similar to Perijá, there are also various natural tourism resources such as waterfalls, viewpoints, pristine Andean forests, and rich biodiversity with great potential for bird watching (e.g. Quetzales and endemic Gorrión del Perijá). Among the strengths identified, Johani confirmed that people are highly committed to the project and to working together as a whole in order to propel tourism in the area and make it a vital economic activity for them. 
For both destinations, the major weakness is the lodging offerings. Both destinations need homestay improvements to ensure visitors have minimum standards such as: bathroom with running water, beds, electricity access, and privacy. Additional recommendations for both destinations include: defining a governance strategy, define a plan for emergency response, training on hygiene and biosecurity protocols (for all lodging, gastronomy, and guidance), training in ophidian accidents, creating an inventory of transport offerings in the areas, and develop marketing and informative material. Both regions also have cultural tourism resources that could be explored (such as traditional dances, music, and crafts).
Result_Title: Detailed tourist plans/packages in Quinchas and Perijá

Project: Empowering territories’ for low carbon transformation
Description:
On May 26-27, 2021, two online workshops on pathways frameworks and long-term vision settings were completed from 9:00 am to 12 pm. The keynote speakers included the Minister of Environment, the National Attorney General Officer for Environmental Affairs, and the Deputy Ambassador to the UK in Colombia. 
Each workshop began with stakeholder engagement dynamics using Mentimeter, an interactive survey software. Then trainers delivered a climate change basic knowledge presentation titled "The truth in 10" by the Climate Reality Project and a presentation on the International policy context for decarbonization pathways and their importance by The Climate Group which included zoom polls to test participants understanding. This was followed by a presentation on Colombia's Long term Strategy 2050 by the Ministry of the Environment. After a break, The Climate Group staff provided a presentation on the process to develop decarbonization pathways and a presentation on how to develop a long-term vision.  These two events were complemented by a live panel made up of Bogota's Advisor to the Municipal Environment Secretary who shared Bogota's experience prioritizing actions and the city's motivation to develop a pathway on Bogota's Climate Action Plan. Both workshops followed the same agenda. May 26 workshop was attended by the 11 secondary state governments and the May 27 workshop was attended by the 5 main beneficiary states. Attendance on May 26 was 234 participants and on May 27, 486 participants from 16 Colombian states.
Result_Title: Online workshops provided to enhance skills of relevant decision makers of 16 department governments for long-term vision for a decarbonization pathway

Project: Proposal of reform to the public policy and legal framework of territorial planning in Colombia in order to comply with the Paris Agreement
Description: Part 1 of the report presents the urban extension and change in land use for municipalities with more than 100,000 inhabitants. An Atlas with the urban footprint was generated with the analysis of 70 municipalities and 10 agglomerations which contains the general view of the evolution of the urban footprint through the last 30 years of the main municipality and its neighboring municipalities. Part 2 of the report contains the relationship between deforestation trends and changes in land use compared to local land use regulations for municipalities of Yopal, Tumaco, Florencia, Cartagena del Chairá, and San Vicente del Caguán. All the results of the analysis will be consolidated in a book that will be presented in November 2021 and the draft pages of Output 1 will be available by the end of June 2021.
Result_Title: Urban Extent Growth and Land Use Change Report

Project: Scaling up rural electrification via capacity building to public and private actors
Description:
April 22, 2021 (Q2 2021) - International Earth Day, GGGI, the Ministry of Mines and Energy (MME), the Institute for Planning and Promotion of Energy Solutions for Non-Interconnected Areas (IPSE) hosted the virtual and public webinar “Working Together for Universal Access to Energy in Colombia” broadcasted live on the MME's youtube channel. The webinar had high-level speakers such as Minister of Mines and Energy, Diego Mesa, GGGI President & Chair, Mr. Ban Ki-moon, and the British Ambassador to Colombia, Colin Martin-Reynolds CMG. 
The objective of the webinar was to:
1) Raise the country ownership of rural electrification support initiatives being delivered by the project. Topics such as the main challenges and opportunities to the global access of energy in Colombia, ways to boost rural electrification, and the role of the private sector in projects of rural electrification were addressed.
2) Discuss the advances and validate the objective, target audience, delivery modality, and content of the “Certified Rural Electrification Project Developer” course. The webinar presented the progress in the development of the course and a set of interactive questions via the MENTI platform to validate the objective, target audience, delivery modality, identified capacity gaps, and content of the training program for the “Formulation and structuring of rural electrification projects with renewable energies”. 
3) Promote the exchange of ideas, lessons learned, and innovative business models around private sector contribution to rural electrification. In the first block of the webinar, there was a panel discussion on the challenges and opportunities of global access to energy in Colombia. Presentations were delivered by representatives of the public and private sectors, including the Director of IPSE, the Director of Electrical Energy of the MME, the Group of Strategic Execution of the Extractive Sector of MME, and the Director of Innova Solar Colombia. 
The event had 230 participants. The video has 1,394 views to date via GGGI´s Facebook page and MME's Youtube site. According to the survey conducted during the event, 76% of the audience came from the public sector and 24% from the private sector.
Result_Title: Webinar with high-level speakers to raise country ownership of rural electrification initiatives, collect feedback, and promote exchange of ideas and lessons learned

Project: Scaling up rural electrification via capacity building to public and private actors
Description:
The Subnational Rural Electrification Working Group was officially initiated on May 15, 2021 with 17 participants (13 men and 4 women) from four subnational territories (Antioquia, Meta, Putumayo, and Chocó). In the first session, there were presentations regarding the objectives and outputs of the project, an overview of the content for the virtual course of "Formulation and structuring of rural electrification projects with renewable energies" and activities such as Mentimeter surveys and questions.
The second working group session was held on June 30, 2021, with 70 representatives (43 men and 27 women) from 19 subnational territories. This second session consisted of knowledge exchange on the financing mechanisms for rural electrification projects, including mechanisms to access funding from FENOGE, FAZNI, and the royalties system.
The Subnational Rural Electrification Working Group was established to facilitate the sharing of best practices and lessons learned among subnational entities. As of June 30, 2021 the Subnational Rural Electrification Working Group has 70 members from 19 departments.
Result_Title: Working group established to convene target sub-national entities

Project: Proposal of reform to the public policy and legal framework of territorial planning in Colombia in order to comply with the Paris Agreement
Description:
On June 10, 2021 (Q2), the webinar "30 años de cambios del uso del suelo en Colombia" (30 years of land-use changes in Colombia) was broadcasted through the different Fedesarrollo social media platforms (Facebook, Twitter, Youtube) in which the results for the Atlas of Urban Expansion and Land-Use Change 2020 were presented, along with analyses and main conclusions from the study. The event had a duration of 2.17 hours. 70 people registered before the event, but there was an audience of 526 people during the webinar. The video has 321 views on Fedesarrollo's YouTube channel to date.
The webinar had the support of Camilo Andrés Quiroz Hinojosa, Director of Urban and Territorial Space, of the Ministry of Housing, Cities and Territory, and Juan Nicolas Galarza Sánchez, Vice Minister of Environmental Planning of the Territory, of the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development, who also made relevant presentations to the topic addressed by the project.
Result_Title: Urban Extent Growth and Land Use Change Event

Project: Expanding the Colombian Climate Asset Disclosure Initiative (CCADI)
Description:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q1-2021]
The first Tools Webinar, out of three, was held on March 18, 2021. The theme of the event was: The Financial Implications of Climate Change. Perspectives and Tools for Addressing Climate Change. 
In the webinar, a total of 20 companies (35 people), corresponding to 7 entities from the financial sector, including banks, pension funds, insurance companies, the central bank, were connected in the specific space to present the climate risk tool.

[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2-2021]
Two webinars were delivered during Q2 2021. The first one was delivered on May 27, 2021. It was a Thematic Workshop on Regulatory trends in the financial risks of climate change and the response from the financial sector which aimed to increase capacities of the financial sector on national and international trends regarding regulation to manage financial risks related to climate change. It had the perspective of both the entities that apply the norms and those that will offer the titles. The event had two sections. The first one was an open webinar through YouTube with 118 attendees. It covered the theoretical context of climate change and information disclosure (TCFD), along with the challenges and opportunities to create regulations to include climate change risks. It also included a panel discussion which concluded that: 1). There are many entities have advanced out of conviction and investment strategy; 2) The joint work between investors and issuers is key, but it remains a challenge; 3). Thematic investments are improving. The second section of the webinar was a private discussion about the Colombian regulation of the financial sector. The main conclusions were: 1) One of the main challenges is to integrate climate risks into traditional risks management systems; 2) The sector is ready to report information, but there may be challenges to acquire depth in the information disclosed; 3). The sector feels that although this issue is of great importance, the regulator is demanding changes at a very high speed. 
The second webinar was delivered on 24 June 2021. It was the second tools workshop on the Financial Risks of Climate Change. It included two breakout rooms to train the attendees on the CCADI and CDP tools to manage climate change risks. 35 people attended this second webinar. One of the suggestions to the CCADI tool included the possibility to measure the ‘financial costs’ if the risks eventually occur.
Result_Title: Series of skill enhancements workshops for capacity building and knowledge sharing between public and private asset owners in Colombia and the UK

Project: Promoting green recovery by championing the power of disclosure, transparency and UK-China collaboration
Description: Technical support for policy makers from local governments (at least one meeting for each supervisory agency of Shenzhen, Shanghai, and Beijing) to exchange research learnings, trends in environment disclosure, and insights.
Result_Title: Enhanced network of sub national supervisory agencies of Shenzhen, Shanghai, and Beijing

Project: Promoting green recovery by championing the power of disclosure, transparency and UK-China collaboration
Description:
"Compile and translate key TCFD technical materials and reports to share with key stakeholders.
Set up web page in Chinese on the TCFD knowledge hub for easy access and dissemination of materials."
Result_Title: Key TCFD technical materials and reports in Chinese. Chinese web page of TCFD knowledge hub

Project: Sustainable Tourism Enhancement Project - Phase 2: Boosting conservation and emissions reduction through tourism and technology
Description: [PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT 2021-Q2] First training on acoustic monitoring to 16 nature tourism organisations and land owners of forest protected areas. The main subjects were: 1) The concepts and details associated to the implementation of acoustic monitoring; 2) The expected impact on tourism; 3) The introduction to biodiversity and monitoring, and technologies to be implemented. The beneficiaries of acoustic monitoring training are located in Meta, Casanare, Cauca, Putumayo, Valle del Cauca and Chocó.
Result_Title: Trainings to local nature tourism organisations on acoustic monitoring system

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support
Description:
The EV Infrastructure Needs Assessment presentation evaluates the impact of electric vehicles on the City's electricity grid. To understand the infrastructure needs, realistic EV uptake scenarios were developed using a vehicle transport model. These scenarios were then workshoped with relevant city officials. These EV uptake forecasts were then translated into infrastructure needs. The presentation documenting the infrastructure needs was developed for City staff. The presentation includes
- Electricity demand forecasts (kWh) and capacity demand forecasts (kW) for City of Joburg
- EV charging requirements (no. of chargers and where they need to be)
- Network requirements and where network strengthening will be required
Result_Title: CoJ EV Infrastructure Needs Assessment

Project: Building the Green Hydrogen Economy (GHE) Just Energy Transition: Co-creating a Just Labour Transition through the TVET College System in South Africa
Description: On 11 May 2021, SAIIA hosted an online visioning workshop with 37 females and 40 males from the Department of Science and Innovation, SAREBI, Sasol Limited, Eskom, Mintek, CSIR, Energy Wand Water SETA, TIPS, SANEDI, uYilo eMobility Programme, The Palladium Group, HySA Catalysis, Bambili Advisor, South African Local Government Association, Blueprint Consulting, DHET, Toyota SA Motors, UK PACT, EWSETA, Engie Hydrogen, British High Commission, University of Cape Town, NBI, Bophelo Impilo Development Centre – BIDC, KPMG, Anglo American, Environmental Affairs, Sasol Foundation, Stellenbosch university and HyPlat..The agenda covered the following : The South African Hydrogen Society Roadmap, Understanding the Green Economy Market and Business Model, Technical and vocational training for the Hydrogen economy, the energy secretariat and green skills transition, skills planning and learning programmes in the hydrogen economy, futures literacy and systemic innovation in the GHE Just Labour Transition. This workshop is the 1st of 2 workshops that will establish/strengthen a Hydrogen Economy Network that sensitizes key industry players to the potential of the hydrogen economy.
Result_Title: Visioning workshops for public-private-partnership dialogue: 2-hour training workshop on the use of strategic foresight, futures literacy, and the Three Horizons methodology

Project: Supporting livelihoods through Ecotourism Routes for Forest and Peace.
Description:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT - Q1 2021] 
MARKETING AND ADMIN WORKSHOP #1: During the first entry to each territory, an introductory workshop to destination marketing and administration for community ecotourism was delivered. It was highly practical and interactive, with various subgroups activities. The first part of the workshop talked about the importance of understanding community marketing (as opposed to individual marketing) and highlighted the benefits of ecotourism for the community (versus focusing on the individual). The second part of the workshop spoke about the principles of marketing, and how these reflected in the user journey when dreaming, booking, experiencing, and sharing a touristic destination. Finally, all the activities that derive from the marketing and administrative roles were discussed and listed, and each person selected 3 roles or tasks they thought would have some experience and knowledge to support the overall marketing task. This allowed the project to observe where there was more knowledge, and the challenges to support in some aspects like the administrative roles, that will need to be supported during the year.

The attendees to these workshops were the people selected in the Marketing Working Group. In Perijá, 9 people attended (2 of them women). In Quinchas, 19 people attached (11 of them women). 

[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2 -2021]
MARKETING WORKSHOP # 2 (TARGETS AND ACTION PLAN). 
Perijá: During June 23 and 24, 2021, the Marketing Working Group's learnings were focused on how to segment clients and project the tourist services. Skills were discovered and strengthened in the marketing and customer service process. The workshop included an introduction to social media, how to publish and how to sell through them, along with the progress of the design of the marketing plan. The participants were very active and participative. Learning by doing keeps the dynamics active in space.
Quinchas: The second marketing workshop with the communities of Las Quinchas was developed at Pizarra-Boyacá on the 18 and 19 of June. The purpose of the workshop was to introduce the marketing group to basic concepts of marketing such as niche market, products, marketing strategy, and digital channels. The idea was to help the participants to identify what target markets they should consider approaching, what needs and interests do these niches have, which of their products respond to their preferences, what messages are appropriate or effective according to what they are looking for, and what channels should they consider to communicate those messages. In the framework of the workshop, an Action Plan was created. It included deadlines, the budget required, leaders, activities to be developed, and success criteria. 
During the workshop, the participants were open-minded and willing to learn and to participate. The conversation was fluid, and they were pointing out good ideas about the topics being discussed and the challenges and opportunities they have. However, there is a risk that they forget or do not consider all the explanations given, hence, it is necessary to do a recap on the next Workshop to evaluate if they truly have kept in mind all the key messages.

MARKETING WORKSHOP # 3 (WEBSITE ADMIN AND USE AND SOCIAL MEDIA)
The training aimed to teach communities to build their own website from scratch in Wordpress. They learned about the basic structure of a website (header, content, footer), basic knowledge of SEO and how content shows itself in different devises (computers, cellphones, etc). The second day, they worked in a practical exercise in a computer (in groups) to learn how to effectively use the different tools and ways to build their own website. This was then applied to the current projects' websites that were created last year, so they appropriated these tools. The final stage of the workshop focused on content creation, especially for social media. A practical exercise was done to learn how to write effective copy that invited the traveler to visit the region, highlighting the main attractions, and pairing the text with an attractive photo or video. The participants were very excited with the content of this workshop, and felt engaged with the practical groups activities.
Result_Title: Community workshops to enhance the capacity of the communities in Quinchas and Perijá to use marketing tools with allocated responsibilities

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support
Description: A comprehensive Briefing Note has been developed titled "Managing EV Uptake in the City of Joburg". The briefing note draws on a comprehensive modelling effort by the SEA team to understand the impact of EVs on Joburg's grid. The briefing note proposes a suitable way forward for City Power (and other municipalities) to deal with EV uptake on distribution grids.
Result_Title: Registration process proposal for private EV chargers

Project: Building the Green Hydrogen Economy (GHE) Just Energy Transition: Co-creating a Just Labour Transition through the TVET College System in South Africa
Description:
TVET Gaps Analysis Report to assess the structural skills training capacity constraints within the TVET college system and lack of alignment with industry skills needs. The objective of the research was to develop a profile of what the current nature of skills required is for the South African Hydrogen Economy (HE) overall, with special focus on Green Hydrogen Economy (GHE) for the future; the current ability and capacity of the TVET system to supply these, assess the gap and provide high level recommendations for intervention where required. The key findings are:  
• As a supplier of technical vocational skills, the South African TVET system is not ready and does not currently have the capacity to provide GE or 4IR skills and training to the level that will be required for the HE or the GHE along the value chain. Current TVET programmes are insufficiently responsive to the needs of industry and the needs of the learners to find viable employment.
• Skills required for the HE as it stands are similar to those needed for industrial chemicals and gases production, storage, and distribution and the TVET system currently does not meet industry needs. There is limited to no on-the-job experience made available to learners and work/life skills are not adequate. Some lecturers have inadequate skills and qualifications as well as limited or no experience with the industry and very limited support is provided to students.
• Skills needed for the GHE are similar to those needed in the HE, but their application in the workplace is not necessarily similar and different content (curricula) and on-the-job exposure is required. At the primary level, some skills will be transferable with additional content and on-the-job training. However, as the value chain progresses downstream, the level of different content and training needed increases significantly.
• Future skills needed will be directly linked to 4IR skills throughout the value chain from the process of primary production through to logistics and complex downstream design and manufacture.
• The gap between the ability of the TVET system as it stands to meet industry needs currently, is typically very large. The implication is that it may be necessary to repurpose TVET architecture as well as systematically review how the system operates. In many cases, industry is dissatisfied with the quality and quantum of graduates. If the supply system itself does not improve in relation to industry demand, even new training content and skills development processes will not be sufficiently helpful to bridge the gap.                                         The following are the recommendations made:                                                                                                                                   •Develop a green skills (including the GHE) Master plan for South Africa. 
•Set up a system of co-planning between industry and TVET colleges at the local level, where hydrogen activities are and will be located. For example, close to SASOL, at outlet ports, and so on. 
•Consider accessing international Green Funds (grant) for the set-up and implementation of a just transition reskilling programme focussing on vulnerable workers and communities. Set up a green skills fund with clear and transparent governance focussed entirely on green skills development (and the GHE skills required) and implementation. 
•Set up a senior private sector led and driven working team (firms and DHET) to review the TVET system in terms of international best practice relevant to green skills development and determine how the system could be redesigned to meet needs, as well as attempting to quantify and qualify skills needed and to ensure collaborative planning into the future. 
•Begin a process of inserting GHE skills needs and priorities into national skills policies and strategies, as well as into the national education system and the sector skills plans for the Sector Education and Training Authorities (SETAs). 
•Urgent TVET budget review is proposed. 
•Step up current efforts to develop improved GHE training and development at the TVET level, and scale them up and focus them. Continue to implement emerging skills training and development in partnership with the TVET college system, in partnership with announced programmes (Sasol, Anglo American and Toyota for example). 
•Content additions to STEM education should be designed and included in curricula, and vocational institutions need to systematically evaluate the generic STEM skills on offer as well as content specific to the hydrogen economy. There should be an immediate focus on incorporating digital skills into all TVET college curricula. 
•Develop a compulsory programme for on-the-job exposure in RE, hydrogen, and FC production for lecturers, potentially via exchange agreements with countries which are further along the production path.
•Consider a post TVET STEM qualification in the short term. There is potential for partnerships with private TVET institutions and other PSET entities.
•	Consider the need for the design and implementation of pathways to clean energy production, jobs, and work at the community level. Potential for pilots in coal mining communities could be prioritised and reskilling implemented using material developed for TVET.
Result_Title: TVET Gaps Analysis Report to assess the structural capacity constraints within the TVET college system and lack of alignment with industry needs

Project: Driving the green agenda through aligning SA's climate-related financial disclosure with best practice
Description: DNA Economics produced 54 fact sheets and one introduction sheet. The purpose of these fact sheets is to provide a view of climate related practices and disclosures from the largest companies on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (JSE) using publicly available data.  This will enable meaningful engagement and decision-making between stakeholders within the asset management and pension fund industries, including companies and funds, industry associations, regulators and standard-setters on material climate-related financial risks and opportunities. Some fact sheets will be incorporated into training sessions with the various beneficiaries and will be used as case study examples to transfer best practice and learnings on company-level climate-related financial disclosure.  The companies covered included : AbINbEV;ABSA,African Rainbow Minerals, Anglo American Plc, AngloGold Ashanti, Arcelor Mittal SA limited, Aspen Pharmacare Holdings Limited, BAT, BId Corporation, Bidvest Ltd, Capitec, Clicks Group Limited, Fin Richemont, Coronation, Discovery, Distell Group Holdings, Exxaro, Fristrand, Glencore, GoldFields, Grwothpoint Properties Limited, Harmony Gold Mining , Impala Platinum Holdings, Investec Plc, Liberty Holdings Limited, Mediclinic, Mondi, Mr Price Group Limited, MTN, Multichoice, Naspers, Nedbank, Northam Platinum, OM Limited, Pepkor Holdings, Prosus, PSG Group Limited, Remgro, RMB Holdings, RHM, Sanlam Limited, Santam Ltd, Sasol Limited, Shoprite, Sibanye Stillwater, South32 Limited, Standard Bank Group Ltd, The Foschini Group Limited, The Spar Group Limited, Tiger Brands, Vodacom, Woolworths,
Result_Title: South Africa  Climate-related Financial Disclosure Fact Sheets

Project: STRAPSA - Shifting the transport  paradigm  for South Africa
Description:
A training manual was produced by Nelson Mandela University for training interventions on electric vehicles. The manual introduced the project, Shifting the Transport Paradigm for South Africa (STRAPSA), project team, uYilo electric mobility programme. The training material is split over two days. On day one the team will provide an introduction to electric vehicles and electric transportation Under introduction to EVs, the following topics were covered : why are EVs needed? Impacts of the status quo, the road to correcting the impacts of the status quo, history of mobility, mobility today, transitions to electric mobility, driving an EV : efficiency, costs and emissions, EV safety and Debunking the myths about EVs. Under electric transportation (road) : the following topics were covered , 2.1 EV ecosystem, electric vehicle landscape, private vehicles, micro mobility for marginalised and vulnerable communities, fleet vehicles and public transport (road).

On day two, the team will provide an introduction to electric vehicle charging infrastructure , electric vehicle landscape, private vehicles, micro mobility for marginalized and vulnerable communities, fleet vehicles and public transport
Result_Title: Training Manual for two-day training intervention on electric vehicles

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support
Description: PARTIALLY ACHEIVED: Q1 2021: 1 day online session with key staff from departments of climate change and air quality, electricity & transport. The workshop aim was to provide an overview of the Johannesburg's EV readiness Support Programme and the local context in relation to electric vehicle development, including existing policies and programmes at the national and local level. It also provided an opportunity for each department to align this project with their department's goals and work plans. It also provided an opportunity to align with the national Department of Transport's Green Transport Strategy.  Total of 20 participants, 15 male, 14 female, and 1 gender not recorded.
Result_Title: Four capacity building sessions with CoJ EV steering committee and relevant national stakeholders

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support
Description: A learning exchange split over two 2-hour sessions with the aim to provide the City of Johannesburg and City of Cape Town the opportunity to share experiences on the implementation of electrical vehicles. The first session took place on the 23 March 2021 and was attended by 21 people (10 male, 11 female) and covered an overview of Cape Town's EV work. The second session took place on the 25 March 2021 and was attended by 22 people (13 male and 9 female), dived into the details of Cape Town's EV energy demand forecast. Detailed inputs were given by the City of Cape Town EV team and robust discussion took place to enable the desired learning exchange.
Result_Title: Two EV learning exchange workshops between City of Cape Town and City of Joburg

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support
Description:
1 day online session with stakeholders from City of Cape Town, City of Johannesburg, City Power, CSIR, Department of Transport, Eskom, Stellenbosch University 's Power Systems Research Group and uYilo. 18 participants attended (10 male and 8 female).
The aim of the workshop was to outline the city's role in electric vehicle uptake and charging infrastructure rollout based on current research and have the invited stakeholders and SEA to share their  relevant research on the grid impacts of EVs. 

The presentation given by CSIR Energy Centre focused on national EV grid impact, while Eskom discussed their e-Mobility project with Stellenbosch University's Power Systems Research Group explored EV hosting capacity on MV (medium voltage) and LV (low voltage) networks. uYilo and the City  of Cape Town focused on enabling EVs in South Africa and Cape Town EV framework respectively. 

The agenda covered the following : key roles played by the City of Johannesburg , key research findings around EV uptake , charging behaviour, charging impact, charging infrastructure requirements, smartification and city ownership , and regulations.  The session included robust debate about best strategies to mitigate EV grid impacts on City Power's grid. City Power's capacity and knowledge was vastly increases.
Result_Title: Capacity building workshop with City Power tariff team on tariff setting for EVs

Project: Accelerating high-quality growth in China’s Green Bond market and supporting post-COVID green economic recovery
Description:
An one-hour discussion between CBI and the Chinese green bond investor community, focusing on the implications of China's carbon neutrality target on green investments, followed by a post-event blog published on 22 June 2021 

Target audience: Green bond investors both international (Blackrock, AIIB,etc.) and Chinese (China Industrial Bank, BOC, ABC, Huaxia Bank, Harvest Fund Management, etc）
Result_Title: Creation of ‘first movers’ to spearhead an investor-led initiative to phase out refinancing of fossil fuel companies.

Project: Accelerating high-quality growth in China’s Green Bond market and supporting post-COVID green economic recovery
Description:
PARTIALLY ACHIEVED: 

A capacity-building workshop is hosted for CBI's approved verifiers in greater China. 24 attendees altogether with 14 F, 7 M and 3 not stated. Objective was to share experience on Financing Credible transitions (entities, activities and assets need to make from today’s high greenhouse gas emissions to levels commensurate with meeting the goals of the Paris Agreement.)
Result_Title: Climate Bonds Assurance Roundtables

Project: Promoting green recovery by championing the power of disclosure, transparency and UK-China collaboration
Description: CDP has completed a Gap Analysis Report that assesses progress that key companies have taken to align business practice to the TCFD. This includes a description of TCFD, and data extracts of assessing the readiness of companies in disclosing in line with the TCFD recommendations.
Result_Title: Report of gap analysis of disclosure status against TCFD alignment of Chinese members of China-UK Pilot group.

Project: Promoting green recovery by championing the power of disclosure, transparency and UK-China collaboration
Description: CDP has completed a research of readiness of Chinese listed companies and FIs for TCFD-aligned disclosure, the report will be launched formally on 29th June at CDP web, download will be available.1 Uploaded is draft Chinese Version submit (EN version will be uploaded at the end of July).
Result_Title: Assessment report of readiness of Chinese listed companies and FIs for TCFD-aligned disclosure

Project: Operationalising Energy Performance Certificates in South Africa
Description: The final report (titled NBEPR Functional and technical specification, and reporting protocols) builds on the functional and non-functional NBEPR requirements first discussed in the previous report (NBEPR User needs, functionality and technical outline, data management and governance policies report) and details the technical specifications to which the NBEPR must be built in order to meet the functional and non-functional requirements. These technical specifications also form the user acceptance criteria for the NBEPR. Further, guidance is provided on the design of the NBEPR database (the robustness of which is key to facilitating data interrogation and reporting, which in turn is expected to inform climate related reporting and policy making) and a number of additional system requirements, including requirements for meeting the needs of people with disabilities. The document is intended to allow for the SANEDI appointed subcontractor to develop a NBEPR that meets user needs and best practices identified in the prior reports.
Result_Title: Policy recommendations for the  National Building Energy Performance Register (NBEPR) delivered to enabling environment actors

Project: Capacity building for green investment and the Green Investment Principles (GIP)
Description:
Baseline assessment report to provide an overview of green finance development in Central Asia to evaluate the development progress and regional best practices in Mongolia, Kazakhstan, and Pakistan, as they have achieved notable progress in regulatory framework and accumulated experience in market practice. The analysis suggests while green finance has taken off in Central Asia, it is still at a preliminary stage. The report identifies several challenges with green finance development (including: lack of systematic regulatory policy, limited institutional coordination, lack of enforcement of environmental disclosure, and gaps in climate related risk management), and provides recommendations in response to these challenges. 

Beneficiary： Financial institutions, government departments, industry organizations, and project owners in Central Asia, as well as NGOs, academic research institutions, etc.

Date of release： End of March.
Result_Title: Green Finance Research Report for Central Asia
Implementor: Beijing Institute of Finance and Sustainability

Project: Sabah Renewable Energy Rural Electrification Road Map
Description:
ACHIEVED:  30 Field Researchers and 43 Field Research Assistants trained as the original core audience (plus 13 other consortium staff) and deployed with guidance documents and three research schedules.
We have trained more people than our target of 60, so that we have additional and reserve staff for deployment if and when needed in particular locations.  This field work is difficult and sensitive, not all field researchers will prove able to manage the typically complex situations on the ground.  Flexibility enabled us to continue training whatever the status of the MCO.  

55% of the Field Researchers/Assistant Field Researchers trained are female.  

 In partnership with KPLB we were able to brief all the relevant District Officers and Assistant District Officers about the project and (with a bumpy start) to develop protocols with them around the communications and protocols for site visits.  Some District Offices also supplied valuable data for project planning.  By 30th June 2021 field teams had visited 40 villages identified under the Demand Map (Output One) to undertake the project portfolio data gathering.  25 Village profiles, 57 Focus Group Discussions and 19 Pre-Feasibility studies were undertaken in these 40 villages by 30th June 2021.  Trial analyses have been undertaken of this first set of data to improve our internal protocols and data management systems.  This work is ahead of schedule, and would have been even more advanced if it had not been for the re-application of MCO-SOPs and the reluctance of some villages to receive visitors during pandemic times.  Our team have done what they can including taking COVID-19 tests, and when possible vaccinations, before field work, and other measures to build trust.  The strategy of training local people from within the target districts is assisting with access, but PACOS is also obliged to innovate a “call-center” approach to data collection in areas where we are not currently allowed to visit.  The goal of 200 Villages profiled is scheduled for completion in October 2021.  Field visits are documenting that many villages are partially electrified, using personal, private or public systems mostly solar and diesel generator.  A more nuanced assessment of levels of electrification will therefore need to be developed for Sabah to understand the demand profile and project portfolio.
Result_Title: Field research training and deployment to develop village data profiles

Project: Distilling the JET in South Africa: Harmonizing conflict and seeking opportunities
Description: On 3 June 2021 TIPS hosted an 2 hour long online workshop titled "Development dialogue : key priorities and challenges for a Just Transition in Emalahleni and Steve Tshwete programme'   .The key speakers were from the Mo Ibrahim foundation, Vukani Environmental Justice Movement in Action (VEJMA),  Chemical, Energy, Paper, Printing, Wood and Allied Workers' Union (CEPPWAWU), Environmental and Waste Management Directorate of  Emalahleni municipality, Minerals Council South Africa and SouthSouthNorth. The audience consisted of 8 non-binary/prefer not say, 116 males and 150 males. The panel was asked how communities can get involved in just transition. The CEPPWAWU speaker indicated that trade unions would likely support renenwable energy if it could be shown to them practically how coal mining workers will still have jobs as the country makes the transition. The VEJMA speaker highlighted the negative social and health impacts of coal mining in these municipalities. The speaker from the Environmental and Waste Directorate of the Emalahleni municipality annouced that the draft climate change strategy will be submitted to the council for approval on 04 June 2021.
Result_Title: Public workshops - the exact topic/agenda is TBC

Project: Harmonisation and capacity building for green finance in Belt and Road Investments
Description:
PARTIALLY COMPLETED: 

"On 24-25 June, we held the first of two training sessions with Chinese financial institutions focused on building awareness and capacity to deal with climate risks, disclosure, and overseas investments.

The training was attended by representatives from some of China’s most influential financial institutions, including the Bank of China, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, the Export-Import Bank of China, the Silk Road Fund, the China Export & Credit Insurance Corporation (Sinosure), the China Agricultural Bank, the China Construction Bank and Ping An Insurance, as well as officials from China’s MEE.

Speakers included prominent names in the sector of green finance, including Dr. Ma Jun, China’s most prominent expert on green finance, Prof. Wang Canfa, an expert on environmental law, as well as Dr. Christoph Nedopil Wang, Dr. Wang Yao, and ClientEarth’s Chief Representative in China, Dimitri de Boer. 

The workshop was highly successful in terms of promoting the outcomes of this project. The participants demonstrated that their institutions were highly aware of the issue of environmental risks in overseas investments, and are searching for ways to deal with the problem. During the workshop many constructive exchanges took place, with the representatives of the financial institutions actively participating, offering their views and learning from others.   The most successful segments were the interactive parts, including a mock-up case study of a hydropower project that ran into major problems."

Among the participants to the workshop were 29 men, 41 women, and 13 participants for whom we did not collect this information.  Unfortunately we failed to collect precise data on the gender of all the participants, but we will do so in the future workshops.
Result_Title: Training workshops with key financial institutions on new environmental risk mitigation systems

Project: STRAPSA - Shifting the transport  paradigm  for South Africa
Description:
First training intervention : DTIC 
On day one 16 delegates received training on an introduction to electric vehicles and electric transportation (road). Under an introduction to electric vehicles, the following topics were covered:  Why are electric vehicles needed?; Impacts of the status quo; The road to correcting the impacts of the status quo; History of mobility; Mobility today; Transitions to electric mobility; Driving an electric vehicle: efficiency, costs and emissions; Electric vehicle safety and Debunking the myths about EVs. Under Electric transportation (road) the following topics will be covered: Electric vehicle system ecosystem; Electric vehicle landscape; Private vehicles; Micromobility for marginalised and vulnerable communities; Fleet vehicles and Public transport (road).

On day two 18 delegates received training on electric vehicle charging infrastructure. The following topics were covered An introduction to electric vehicle charging infrastructure; Publicly accessible chargers, Electric busses and Ancillary services from electric vehicle fleets. 

Audience : Senior Management within the Industrial Development Division: Green Industries; Automotive Sector. Senior Staff within the Industrial Development Corporation (IDC); Senior Staff within Invest SA; Senior Staff within International Trade Administration Commission (ITAC).

Second training intervention : Western Cape government 
On day one 21 delegates received training on an introduction to electric vehicles and electric transportation (road). Under an introduction to electric vehicles, the following topics were covered:  Why are electric vehicles needed?; Impacts of the status quo; The road to correcting the impacts of the status quo; History of mobility; Mobility today; Transitions to electric mobility; Driving an electric vehicle: efficiency, costs and emissions; Electric vehicle safety and Debunking the myths about EVs. Under Electric transportation (road) the following topics will be covered: Electric vehicle system ecosystem; Electric vehicle landscape; Private vehicles; Micromobility for marginalised and vulnerable communities; Fleet vehicles and Public transport (road).

On day two 21 delegates received training on electric vehicle charging infrastructure. The following topics were covered An introduction to electric vehicle charging infrastructure; Publicly accessible chargers, Electric busses and Ancillary services from electric vehicle fleets. 

Audience : Senior Staff within the Western Cape Government and Western Cape Local Government (City of Cape Town). Two Graduates in Training working for Western Cape Government. One Student working for Western Cape Local Government (City of Cape Town)
Result_Title: Seven 2-day training workshops  with personnel (key decision makers) from various national departments

Project: Sustainable Tourism Enhancement Project - Phase 2: Boosting conservation and emissions reduction through tourism and technology
Description: [PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT 2021-Q2]  The Marketing Strategy was created. It contains the tactics and actions that will be carried out for the commercialization of 10 destinations, while giving visibility to conservation initiatives. After doing a general diagnosis and a DOFA and PESTELT analysis to prioritise the destinations to be commercialised, the following 10 destinations were selected: Bahía Malaga, Puerto Nariño, Casanare, Río Guejar (Meta), Nuquí, Inírida, La Macarena, Mocoa - Orito, Ipiales and Cali surroundings. The analysis also included collection of travelers' perceptions through surveys. The implementation of the marketing strategy started in May and has been active for three months. Up until 30 June 2021, total sales were of COP $429,331,151 (GBP 78,000 approx) in Villaviencio, Putumayo, La Macarena, Guainía , Nuquí, Río Güejar and Puerto Nariño.
Result_Title: Commercialization strategy and high-quality audiovisual content that showcases the tourism experiences, hosts conservation efforts, impact of GHG emission reduction, and the results of the monitoring and measurement pilot program

Project: The development of a Green Economy Cluster organisation to support Mpumalanga's role in the validation, implementation and follow-on research of the South African Renewable Energy Industry Masterplan (SAREM)
Description:
This document provides a breakdown of the current progress of the South African Renewable Energy Masterplan. It provides a consolidated view of stakeholder inputs towards workstreams for identified plan actions/levers. This is an important step in ensuring that the SAREM and its recommended actions are pragmatic, sensible and will lead to the desired outcomes. This record of emerging workstreams and potential levers forms a reference for discussion to prioritize focus and refine and validate implementation plan elements.

Six specialist focus groups were held to formulate a shortlist of opportunities, market bottlenecks, required drivers and potential levers in a specific focus area draft SA Renewable Energy Masterplan. 

(i) Industry reference focus group - energy planning (sector coupling) :  A focus group workshop was held on 7 April 2021. This workshop was lead by GreenCape and The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR). The discussion focused on unlocking the significant opportunities associated with the hydrogen economy, hydrogen export potential and sector coupling of heat and transport to the power sector. The list of proposed levers was categorized
into Policy and Markets, Technology and Infrastructure, and Financing.

(ii) Industry Reference Focus group – Electricity planning :As part of the process for defining a long list of levers for the electricity planning focus group, a focus group workshop was held on 7 April 2021. This workshop was lead by GreenCape and Meridian Economics.  In general, the key levers that surfaced from the workshop were focused on stimulating the increased uptake of renewable energy in South Africa’s power sector. Levers were categorized into four main focus areas: market development and regulatory reforms, technical advancements to the transmission network, the role of policy and potential financial interventions that could be implemented.

(iii) Industry   Reference Focus group – Just Transition: As part of the process for defining a long list of levers for the Just Transition focus group, a focus group workshop was held on 8 April 2021. This workshop was lead by GreenCape and Trade & Industrial Policy Strategies (TIPS). As part of an overall, broad strategy and mix of measures, the renewable energy sector can make a positive contribution towards a just transition on at least three key levels: the rollout of renewable energy-based electricity generation can provide a source of economic activity and employment through the deployment (project planning and design, procurement, construction/installation, operation and maintenance) of large-scale power plants and small-scale systems; renewable energy technologies provide a platform to enhance the access to modern energy services by all, including through increased new ownership models; and the development of the renewable energy value chain, from the mining and beneficiation of minerals to the manufacturing of parts, components and systems, to the recycling of components, can generate economic activity and employment in the country.

(iv)Industry Reference Focus group – Transformation :As part of the process for defining a long list of levers  for the Transformation focus group, a focus group workshop was held on 8 April 2021. This workshop was lead by GreenCape and Letsema.  Some of the key challenges that have hindered the participation of marginalised groups are as follows: limited access to finance by Black people in ownership deals; high costs of Black equity financing; the limited flow of benefits in  community ownership trust structure and here is no strategic development of Black people for management role


(v)Industry Reference Focus group – Skills : There were several skills development desktop studies initiated before and around the publishing of the Integrated Resource Plan 2010, which culminated in the intervention of creating the South African Renewable Energy Technology Centre (SARETEC), an initiative of the Department of Higher Education & Training (DHET) and the National Skills Fund (NSF). SARETEC was mandated to undertake targeted skills training of operations and maintenance skills for the wind and solar renewable energy sector. SARETEC, hosted by the Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT), aimed to train local skills to replace foreign technicians working on South African renewable energy power plants after the implementation of REIPPPP( Renewable Energy Independent Power Producer Procurement Programme) Round 1 and 2 projects. The impact of SARETEC on the local skills landscape was measured by subsequent research like the Tracer Studies undertaken between the GIZ and Altgen Consulting. More recent skills development studies with the onset of  Bid Windows 3 and 4 included  the following: GreenCape Green Economy Skills Audit, Altgen, 2019 Report;. An Overview of the Employment Implications of the South African Power Sector Transition, Based on research undertaken by Meridian Economics on behalf of SAWEA, July 2018;A Just Energy Transition in South Africa, Socio-economic needs and the positive impacts of a future low carbon economy. Compiled by RES4Africa in partnership with CSIR & ERM, 2020;Future skills and job creation through renewable energy  in South Africa, CSIR Renac,  IET, UfU & IASS Potsdam,  March 2019;SAPVIA Solar PV Industry Jobs Report, Literature Review, CSIR on behalf of SAPVIA, April 2021.Some of the main outcomes from the above studies include that the lack of certainty in the REIPPPP nullifies any large scale predicted skills shortage in renewable energy. South Africa can significantly boost employment by increasing the share of renewables with jobs concentrated in the services, construction and manufacturing sectors and the bulk of job creation being in the high-skilled labour group. Consideration should be given to a reskilling hub to take advantage of the opportunities renewables offer across the energy value chain to mitigate job losses. Jobs vary substantially between the asset construction and O&M phases, with more jobs in the construction phase than the O&M phase for solar PV; hence continuous rollout of new PV projects is critical to creating new skills and jobs. Finally, the employment implications of the power sector transition are highly complex and dynamic and validating suitably complex and diverse analysis to enhance user understanding of the skills required is a critical aspect.

(v)  Industry Reference Focus group – Export: a  thriving local renewable energy manufacturing sector requires South Africa to be a competitive exporter of renewable energy components, systems and services. The limited focus on driving industrialization and the gap in the REIPPPP process means that South Africa may have missed “window the opportunity” to be a base for exporting to other markets (including future renewable energy projects in Africa), especially as other emerging economies have stepped into the renewable  energy (manufacturing) space in the interim. At the same time, stakeholders have indicated that an export market (i.e. additional demand for components, skills and services) may be required to provide economies of scale for local manufacturing in South Africa. Additional insights are needed to understand and deconstruct this opportunity.   There have been several instances of South African manufacturers of key components exporting locally manufactured components. In particular, Jinko Solar, Tenesol, and Art Solar have  all been exported. GRI, the tower manufacturer, also exported temporarily to keep the factory productive. Many others chose to close down manufacturing facilities as the export opportunity was not sufficient to enable them to continue (e.g. SMA, AEG, SunPower). The global market for Renewable energy components is growing rapidly year on year. This means that new manufacturers can compete in a growing market. Global dynamics like antidumping duties and various domestic manufacturing policies in big manufacturing markets (like China) have big impacts on the competitiveness of locally manufacturing components. Between preferred bidder status and financial close, the IPPO allows a portion of the bid tariff to fluctuate with the exchange rate – this creates
a possible lever for locally manufactured projects and the amount of the tariff that can float on the global risk be decreased round by round.
