Taking into account the SAREM outcomes, the drivers and barriers that have been identified by industry, labour and government stakeholders, ten SAREM workstreams have been proposed in chapter 6 of the report: market consistency/certainty/growth, industry transformation; the development of a local content policy; input materials cost and availability; trade support/export support to access regional opportunities; system readiness; new entrant support/incentives/barrier; local manufacturing competitiveness; creation and support of a skills hub (local use and export skills); and just transition hotspots.

Subject to no impediments to  the process arising, the draft plan is expected to be reviewed and the final plan adopted for implementation by the industry, government, labour and social partners during the 2021-2022 financial year.
Result_Title: SAREM Validation Report

Project: Driving the green agenda through aligning SA's climate-related financial disclosure with best practice
Description:
Produced two reports, the first " Climate-related Financial Disclosure in South Africa", introduces climate-related financial disclosure and motivates for better and more disclosure by South African institutions. It is intended as a resource for readers who want to motivate for disclosure within their institutions. In summary the report covers why climate-related financial disclosure is useful, introduced the Task force on Climate-related Financial Disclosure, described the main types of climate-change related financial impacts, reviewed climate-related financial disclosure trends internationally, considered the local factors influencing disclosures and described the current state of climate-related financial disclosure. 

The second report, “Climate-related disclosures for financial institutions”, provided a review of international best practices for climate disclosures relevant to South African financial institutions. The report discussed (i) the landscape of global climate-related disclosures and best practices, (ii) reporting in  line with TCFD recommendations and details of TCFD disclosure for financial institutions, (iii) relevant metrics and methodologies, (iv) best practices for scenario analysis and (v) local context for South African financial institutions.
Result_Title: Trends in Climate-related Financial Disclosure Report: What Does it Mean for South Africa

Project: Driving the green agenda through aligning SA's climate-related financial disclosure with best practice
Description: PARTIALLY ACHIEVED: Quarter 2 2021: Produced a 16 page special edition publication, Climate-related financial disclosure-aligning South Africa to global best practice, was published on Atleha-edu website summarising the learnings from the 53 fact sheets and reports on climate-related financial disclosure in South Africa and climate-related disclosures for financial institutions. It introduced South Africa-UK PACT programme and climate risk (describing physical and transition risks and impacts on policy, reputation and markets). Moreover, climate risk analytics for sustainable investment, an overview of climate risk and investment, climate risk and scenario analysis, climate risk and corporate reporting were covered with a Financial Sector Conduct Authority (FCSA) Guidance Note on sustainability of investments, and investment opportunities presented the transition to low-carbon economies were discussed. The publication ended with a short questionnaire.
Result_Title: Online publications of learnings from report and factsheets on Climate Finance Disclosure in South Africa, including audio visual products.

Project: The development of a Green Economy Cluster organisation to support Mpumalanga's role in the validation, implementation and follow-on research of the South African Renewable Energy Industry Masterplan (SAREM)
Description:
As South Africa undergoes several different transitions, there is a need for an inclusive social order that brings labour, government, and business into an agreement. This inclusive social order is the role of the social compact, whereby each partner commits to implement concrete interventions to realise specific economic objectives with a sector, e.g. job creation. To ensure key stakeholders are targeted, GreenCape have produced three stakeholder maps. The first is government and state-owned entities, which includes two key government departments with direct support from three others: the Department of Mineral Resources and Energy (DMRE) (responsible for the oversight of the plan’s development). 

The second is the renewable energy industry stakeholder mapping, which is split into industry groupings for the social compact and value chain groupings for industry. This includes the original equipment manufacturer, local renewable energy manufacturers, project developers, investors, members of South African Photovoltaic Industry Association, and members of South African Renewable Energy Council. The third is the organised labour stakeholder mapping. There is currently no Renewable Energy labour union which means different workers across the value chain are represented by different unions. Labour unions included in the map are: The Federation of Unions of South Africa, Congress of South African Trade Unions, Solidariteit, Chemical, Energy, Paper, Printing, Wood and Allied Workers' Union, National Union of Mineworkers, and National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
Result_Title: SAREM Social Compact Mapping (industry champions of change)

Project: Climate Transition Pathways
Description:
Q3 2020
CEO Launch event: The CEO launch event was held on 28 July 2020 to much public interest and support from the South African business community. This CEO launch event milestone was held and attended by amongst others, the CEO’s of the country’s two most carbon intensive companies as per CDP – Eskom and Sasol. A sizeable number of CEOs from leading companies and key industry bodies have been recruited to champion the project. Leveraging the convening power of the NBI and BUSA (Business Unity South Africa). At the time of reporting 24 CEOs of listed companies agreed to be CEO champions, as well as the Johannesburg Stock Exchange and various industry bodies. On-boarding of more CEO’s is ongoing.
Q4 2020
CEO Champions Advisory Meeting: Pathways for the electricity sector to "Net Zero" by 2050. This meeting took place on 15th November 2020 and counted with the participation of 49 representatives from a diversity of companies, of which 20 were women. The meeting introduced the core project team, explained the scope of work for the project and its contribution to the South African climate targets and the just transition. The project explained the focus areas of the project in 2020 and provided an overview of the analysis and findings for the electricity sector, their modelling approach, the role of the just transition, and its links to broader social and economic agendas in the country. The feedback from the participants was positive overall.
Q1 2021
CEO Champions Advisory Meeting: Business Action for Sustainable Growth. This meeting took place on 24th February 2021 and counted with the participation of 34 representatives from a diversity of companies, of which 13 were women. The purpose of the meeting was to share key findings from modelling exercises in the electricity sector and petrochemicals sectors and the initial review for just transition for coal value was completed. The agenda also covered achieving a net zero power mix, decarbonizing South Africa’s petrochemicals sector and the role of gas in energy transition in South Africa. The meeting ended with a discussion of the next steps which would be work in agriculture, forestry and other land use and transport sector.
Q2
On 01 July 2021, NBI hosted a CEO champions meeting. The objective of the meeting was to discuss the international policy context and process related to COP26, introduce, "Business statement on the Just Transition", provide an overview of progress and latest findings, present planned publication series and share the "CEO Guide".
Result_Title: CEO Champions Advisory Meetings

Project: Paving the Way for Setting Ambitious GHG Emissions Reductions in the Private Sector to enhance the National Climate Change Policy
Description:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT - Q2 2021]
Two workshops took place:
1.- A workshop for the staff of Procuraduria Federal de Proteccion al Ambiente (PROFEPA), which focused on giving an introduction to the SBT initiative (SBTi) and how this initiative could be linked to the Programa Nacional de Auditoría Ambiental (PNAA).
2.- A workshop with Comisión Nacional Bancaria y de Valores (CNBV) with 6 sessions about: (i) Introduction to the workshop, (ii) Climate change science and Mexico's commitments, (iii) Climate change and the finance sector, (iv) Introduction to the SBTi, (v) Introduction to SBT methodologies for the finance sector, and (vi) Deep dive into the finance sector SBT tools

The third workshop with Comisión Nacional de Mejora Regulatoria (CONAMER) was not achieved during Q2 as there were internal changes to their team. The third workshop is to be held in Q3.
Result_Title: 3 tailored workshops for government beneficiaries on corporate climate action

Project: Assessment of the greenhouse gas mitigation potential of hydrogen. An implementation roadmap for Mexico
Description: The dissemination event took place on June 1, 2021, on the topic "Green hydrogen opportunities for Mexico: An international review of technologies and experiences." The event gathered a group of 127 participants (37% were female and 63% were male). Welcome speechs were given by the British Ambassador to Mexico, a General coordinator from Instituto Nacional de Ecología y Cambio Climático (INECC), and the Executive Director of Centro Mario Molina (CMM). The presentations were given by representatives from CMM, Imperial College London, British Petroleum, Cambridge and World Bank.
Result_Title: Webinar on the opportunities for green hydrogen in Mexico and presentation of the existing technologies and experiences

Project: Assessment of the greenhouse gas mitigation potential of hydrogen. An implementation roadmap for Mexico
Description: The report developed is a review of (i) green hydrogen technologies in the energy and industry sectors, (ii) national & international case studies of green hydrogen production projects, and (iii) costs associated with hydrogen generation, storage, transmission, distribution, and end uses.
Result_Title: Review and analysis of state of the art technologies for green hydrogen production and use in the energy and industry sectors

Project: Consolidation of the Mexican Climate Finance Hub - mobilizing resources to mitigation and adaptation activities and achieve Mexico´s emission reduction goals
Description: The briefing developed elaborates on (i) the barriers and opportunities to finance green infrastructure developed by subnational entities in Mexico, (ii) the relevance of private-public partnerships as a mechanism to finance such infrastructure, as well as (iii) the best practices to access financing as a subnational entity in four different stages of developing a project (feasibility, development, and operation).
Result_Title: Briefing for subnational entities on green funding and project finance for green infrastructure

Project: Landscape conservation and livelihood restoration in the Mexican ejidal altiplano: the case of Apan, Hidalgo.
Description:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2 2021]

Dissemination Event 1 of 3: IP presented the impact of climate change in the Altiplano and the 5 main issues identified in the diagnostic report for each of the following topics: water, soil and biodiversity. There were 4 sessions with 45 participants in total. Participants shared other possible issues with the audience.
Result_Title: Targeted dissemination of products for transparency and information directed towards beneficiaries and local stakeholders
Implementor: Eetestudio  (Espacio entre tiempo estudio SA de CV)

Project: Landscape conservation and livelihood restoration in the Mexican ejidal altiplano: the case of Apan, Hidalgo.
Description:
The diagnostic report was developed, covering: (i) the definition of land territory of Apan, (ii) its recent history and main socio-environmental trends, (iii) main socio-environmental issues related to climate change (including a climate change prospective scenario, threatened hydraulic resources, soil erosion, disappearance of local biodiversity, governance and inequality issues, and main socioeconomic issues).

In addition, a legal annex was developed. This annex documents the federal and local constitutional frameworks of water and water concessions for Apan.
Result_Title: Diagnostic report on shared knowledge of the territory’s current and future prospects under climate change
Implementor: Eetestudio  (Espacio entre tiempo estudio SA de CV)

Project: Strengthening the use of Earth Observation platforms to support the implementation of climate change mitigation goals in the forest and land use sector in three states in Mexico.
Description:
IP set up an inter-institutional mapping working group to discuss definitions, criteria, methods and best practices for mapping land cover/use and land cover/use change. The first meeting was held on the May 27th and 31st where CONAFOR, SIAP, ECOSUR and INEGI presented objectives, definitions, classes, inputs, products, processing methods and tools, post-processing and accuracy evaluation of their mapping methods. 
12 men and 12 women participated.

A second meeting was held on the June 10, 2021, where user cases were presented by SEMAHN, FEMEXPALMA, and the state government of Tabasco. Ecosistemas presented a comparative table of methods and classifications. Ecosistemas also demoed an EO Lab application that compared different maps in Chiapas that was set up by ECOSUR.
10 women (28%) and 26 men (72%) participated.
Result_Title: Inter-institutional working group formed between at least three national and six state institutions responsible for agreeing on criteria to monitor the agricultural frontier to monitor progress towards the net zero deforestation goal
Implementor: Ecometrica Ltd. (Ecosistemas Consultoría Integral para Soluciones sustentables)

Project: Strengthening the use of Earth Observation platforms to support the implementation of climate change mitigation goals in the forest and land use sector in three states in Mexico.
Description:
"Ecosistemas Consultoría completed the draft of the analysis of the platforms, which included a technical analysis and effectiveness evaluation, based on findings from the online seminar on “Geographical Information Platforms and Their Use in Public Policy” (April 28-29th), as well as user interviews and questionnaires for the administrators.

The report was sent to the platform administrators on July 10th, and a final version  was shared with beneficiaries and partners on July 14th. Platforms included in the analysis are SINACIC, MARACC, ECOSUR EO Labs, SAMOF, and Observatorio de la Selva Maya."
Result_Title: Evaluation Report on Climate Monitoring and Mitigation Actions
Implementor: Ecometrica Ltd. (Ecosistemas Consultoría Integral para Soluciones sustentables)

Project: Technical assistance for developing sustainable energy access strategies in Mexico
Description:
Puebla:
4-day training with multiple government senior managers and managers.
The final result was to align with the Agencia de Energía with Bienestar so they can start working on an energy access program in the state (Bienestar was already working on this initiative).
Veracruz:
4-day training with multiple government senior managers and managers. On the final day, a plan was set to focus on a few municipalities for the visits so the Agencia de Energía can present the results to a potential funding partner.
Yucatán:
4-day training with multiple government senior managers and managers. During these sessions, there was an active participation from CFE, and the Agencia signed a collaboration agreement to share knowledge as a result of the workshop."
Result_Title: 4-day workshops with State Energy Agency on designing energy access programs in 3 states in Mexico (Puebla, Veracruz and Yucatán)
Implementor: Ilumexico (Eres Energía Renovable SAPI de CV)

Project: Strengthening the Legislative-Executive-Stakeholder dialogue on Mexico's climate change and energy goals at the national and subnational levels
Description:
[Event 1] A virtual meeting to kick-off of the Joint Collaboration event with participation of legislators from the Commission of Protection of the Environment and Climate Change (CPMACCPEA) in Mexico City’s Congress, the British Embassy, Mexico City Secretary of Environment (SEDEMA), and POLEA advisors.

[Event 2] The virtual event was held for the Participatory Process of Elaboration of a Circular Economy Law Initiative, with emphasis on combating Climate Change in Mexico City. Participation of 3 deputy members from the Commission for the Preservation of the Environment, Climate Change and Ecological and Animal Protection (CPMACCPEA) from the Congress of Mexico City; representatives from the British Embassy, the Ministry of the Environment (SEDEMA), Economic Development (SEDECO) of the Government of Mexico City, international institutions, and civil society organizations.
Result_Title: Two high-level event forums in Mexico City with legislators at the local level

Project: Accelerating Fleet-wide electrification of public transport in Mexico City
Description: GPS data was collected from the 7 existing Metrobus lines that will be used to conduct energy analysis. The document describes the methodology and variables captured and other considerations for analysis.
Result_Title: Report on GPS data collected for Metrobus lines
Implementor: Dalberg Advisors (Asesores en Desarrollo Dalberg S. de R.L.)

Project: Technical assistance for the implementation of emergent design for active mobility and public space
Description:
The guide was developed and contains the following three sections:
- The first section is about general information as prologue and introduction.
- The second section is about 'Territorial management', which includes the following tools: i) to gather information, ii) to consult, iii) to dialogue, iv) to co-create, v) to active interventions, and vi) to communicate. 
- The third section is about 'Communication', which includes tactics, communication media, campaign structure and examples with creativity. In the last section are the references and the annexes with formats.

The publication presents tools to guide the inclusion of priority groups in decision making. It includes 20 additional recommendations to strengthen the tools (i.e. having mixed teams for site visits and considering different timeframes / preparing specific activities for the involvement of children).
Result_Title: Guide for local governments to communicate emergent strategies for active mobility and public space projects

Project: Green Finance for the development of Smart Cities in Mexico II, working to accelerate the implementation of low carbon local projects and sustainable development
Description: 2 training sessions were delivered to beneficiary cities on the identification and evaluation procedure & methodologies to select projects for green finance mechanisms access. There were 13 participants in total, from the cities of Chihuahua, Hermosillo, Villahermosa and Zapopan, representing NGOs, government, and the private sector.
Result_Title: Training sessions to enhance capacities of city public servants to identify and evaluate potential projects for green finance mechanisms

Project: Supporting livelihoods through Ecotourism Routes for Forest and Peace.
Description:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT 2021 Q2]
From June 21-24th, a culinary tourism course was held in Perijá. It was directed by Jennifer Rodriguez and her team (one biologist and one anthropologist, both empirical cooks). The course was divided in two parts: (1) the importance of costing and portioning, (2) the use of food waste in other food products, such as using banana peel to make vinegar. 
The cooking began by using traditional regional products such as moringa and cilantro in different and innovative preparations like mojos and pestos, as well as different sauces and dips with traditional chilies. Also, other preparations were done that were going to be needed for the next day. The second day of the course was dedicated to creating a complete lunch menu with different options and ways of using traditional ingredients from the people's orchards. 3 main groups of food were developed: i) soups, salads and sides, ii) animal protein (in this case fish), and iii) desserts using the fruits from the region. The audience was highly engaged, empowered, and devoted to their different tasks, and the final result was a variety of delicious, nutritious, healthy, balanced and local, participatory meals, cooked by all the community members (mostly woman) interested in the gastronomic and culinary element of tourism.
Result_Title: Culinary course that incorporates native or traditional ingredients worth showcasing for touristic purposes in Quinchas and Perijá

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description:
In Q2, the dedicated website was completed. It describes the challenges, opportunity, solution, activities, and why Meta/Colombia.
It is hosted on Rare's website: https://rare.org/program/transforming-smallholder-agriculture/
Result_Title: Dedicated webpage for the project

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2 2021]
During Q2, Precision Development (PxD) worked on the integration of the back-end platform, Paddy, and the telecom aggregator’s systems, Sinch (formerly Wavy). The first SMS messages were sent to farmers during June 2021. 
Paddy is a toolkit developed by PxD for building two-way communication platforms with a high degree of automation. In programming terms, Paddy is more like a library than an application. The library contains a set of reusable modules that we can choose to deploy in different combinations for each new service launched. Paddy can run on a variety of backends, for example, SMS platforms, IVR (Interactive Voice Response) platforms, or chatbots on WhatsApp or Telegram. Paddy collects detailed usage data and generates tabular data like that by SurveyCTO/ODK. It is very easy to add randomization to the platform logic for implementing A/B tests or RCTs. Logic can vary based on user data, so different groups of users can be served through different platform configurations and content.
As of June, SMS were sent to a data base of more than 2,000 farmers with agronomic advice on the climate-smart practices that the project is promoting. For the kick-off, a welcome message was sent informing that the service has been developed as part of the UK PACT project, that the messages will be received weekly free of charge, and that the objective is to help improve crop productivity and sustainability. The first set of messages corresponds to cross-cutting practices, starting with soil management. Six topics are being covered in total: i) organic matter, ii) cover crops, iii) erosion, iv) burning, v) soil analysis and vi) fertilization. For each thematic, 12 messages have been delivered. In June, the topic addressed was organic matter with specific aspects on composting: benefits and how to do it.
Result_Title: Ongoing mobile-based technical support to farmers on climate smart agriculture

Project: Accelerating development of new bioeconomy businesses and enhanced capacities for green jobs promotion and increased climate action ambition from policy implementation and integration.
Description:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2-2021]
Key advances have been made by prioritizing the actions of the green growth policy's action plan and the sustainable economic reactivation policy according to the following criteria: i. Level of influence or direct impact, ii. Linkage to other actions, iii. Materiality of the action based on the size of the goal and the associated investment amount. 
A report has been developed that details a consultation and assessment of information from different sources such as the Territorial Green Growth Index, the Climate change MRV system, Sinergia system, Sisconpes, Sisclima, and SDG's reporting schemes. The report also provides a detailed assessment of implementation progress and planned activities under the current National Development Plan 2018 – 2022. The project team is currently advancing on assessing at least three interinstitutional working agendas that involve SD´s, Green Growth Policy, and NDC implementation to identify possible recommendations for the upcoming National Development Plan 2022-2026 (activity 5.3). The interinstitutional agendas prioritized are 1. Productive Development Policy 2. National Forest Agenda 3. Circular Economy Strategy 4. Bioeconomy Mission and 5. Comprehensive Climate Change Management Plan for the Mining and Energy Sector - PIGCC.
Result_Title: Low-carbon and green growth recommendations delivered to serve as part of the basis for the upcoming National Development Plan (NDP) 2022-2026 based on the progress of GGP, green recovery, and the 2030 agenda implementation

Project: Accelerating development of new bioeconomy businesses and enhanced capacities for green jobs promotion and increased climate action ambition from policy implementation and integration.
Description:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT  Q2-2021] 
On May 12, 2021, GGGI, SENA and UK PACT held an open and virtual panel discussion on the importance of generating green jobs for the sustainable reactivation of Colombia. In this space, all three parties announced the partnership and the project itself, presenting key expected results. Mr. Ambassador Colin Martin-Reynolds, Ambassador of the United Kingdom in Colombia and Carlos Mario Estrada, General Director of SENA, opened the event, followed by the panel discussion with Andrea Constanza Tibaquira - Curriculum Management Coordinator of SENA, Alejandra Ospitia - Executive Director of FEDEMADERAS, Santiago Briceño - Director of International Climate Finance and Clean Growth Programs of the British Embassy in Colombia, and Carolina Jaramillo, Colombia CR of GGGI. The panel was streamed live on SENA's youtube channel and so far has 1,677 views to date. The panel is a cross cutting result across the development of all three sectorial knowledge networks. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dkNBtkdPwwM

In addition, during Q2, GGGI advanced on strengthening and reinvigorating SENA's Electrical Energy
Sectorial Knowledge Network. The network met on June 2nd to evaluate and validate with key private and public energy stakeholders regarding the profiles of potential students for the Technological Energy Efficiency program. This is especially important considering that part of the role of the Energy Network is to confirm what type of student is required for the program and more importantly, what type of graduate does the energy sector needs as potential employees. The objective was achieved through a 4-hour meeting with different types of interventions, feedback, propositions and comments, as well as filling in an evaluation form.
Result_Title: Three SENA sectorial knowledge networks strengthened and reinvigorated in low-carbon labour force development

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description: The teaching material for the 90-hour course was developed, containing module contents, slide packs and syllabus. The material comprehends topics on Introduction to Behaviour Change, Local Governance, Leadership Skills, Andragogy, Climate Change and Agriculture, Behaviour Change, and CSA.
Result_Title: Training materials for the 6 module diploma course on Behaviour Change, Local Governance, Leadership Skills, Andragogy, Climate Change and Agriculture, and CSA

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description:
Four guides on priority practices were developed on the following topics: 1) Guide on micro-organisms, 2) Guide on how to make compost, 3) Guide on how to use agroclimatic information, 4) Guide on soil health. 
Through focus groups with producers and extension workers, it was possible to review and adjust the contents to make them simple and easy to understand, as well as guarantee that the information presented was pertinent and relevant to the type of producer the project is working with. Feedback was also important in the process to make materials more attractive and adjusted to the context of the area.
Result_Title: CSA printed guides and digital tutorials on new agronomic practices addressed to farmers

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT 2021 Q2]
Webinars with municipal mayors, agriculture, environmental authorities, and state-level authorities from five prioritized municipalities (Cubarral, Lejanías, El Dorado, El Castillo, Granada)  were held on the 25, 27, 28, and 31 of May. With this set of webinars, it was possible to present the objectives, main activities, and progress made by the New Technologies Project, practices to transform the agricultural sector in Colombia. Also to discuss the adoption of practices to boost rural development in sustainable ways. These webinars helped to identify the common ground and goals between the project and the participant institutions.
In El Castillo municipality, 11 members of the municipal council participated. At the departmental level, the Secretary of Agriculture, officials from Cormacarena (Noreco), and officials from the Orinoquía's BioCarbono Fund were present. There were 47 participants in total, of which 24 were women (51%).
Result_Title: Working sessions and events to strengthen Authorities network within 5 municipalities on CSA practices and sustainable landscapes

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description:
During May, workshops with municipal authorities of Cubarral, El Dorado, Granada, and Lejanías were developed. On June 24th, the workshops were completed since the workshop with the Governor's Office from El Castillo was delivered.
Through these workshops it was possible to provide information on behaviour change methodologies, climate-smart agriculture practices, and an introduction to climate change issues, which helped to motivate commitment towards the implementation of CSA at landscapes levels.
The workshops had a participation of 15 attendants, of which 7 were women (47%).
The material, agenda, and attendance registers from the training sessions are available as evidence.
Result_Title: 5 x 4-hour workshops with municipal authorities on behaviour change, climate change literacy, and climate-smart agricultural practices

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description:
250 farmers agreements signed (78 with female producers, corresponding to 31%) to cooperate with soil analysis, compost processes, and be part of the training sessions.
1-day training workshop with farmer innovators from the 5 prioritized municipalities on an introduction to climate-smart agricultural practices and climate change with emphasis on i) Soil management, ii) Benefits of composting / how to properly process compost, and iii) Importance of gathering climatic information for efficient irrigation.
The purpose of these trainings is that farmer innovators understand the importance of soil components (chemical, physical and biological) and the relationship between soil and rainwater absorption.
Result_Title: 5 x 1-day training workshops with farmer innovators on climate-smart agricultural practices and climate change

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description:
Universidad de Los Llanos agreed to collaborate with the development of this 90-hour course. The course had a participation of 48 extension agents total, and in a closing ceremony through a webinar on May 21, participants shared some examples of the social marketing material that they have developed. The 48 extension agents will be receiving a certificate of completion for this diploma course, from which 44% of the total are women. Material from the different sessions of the course on "Changing behaviour tools for sustainability in the agricultural sector" is presented, and training feedback via surveys as well, which are already registered in the training questionnaires in the RMS.
The course helped to enhanced the skills of extension agents and provide tools for them to interact with farmers and offer technical assistance for the sustained adoption of climate-smart agriculture practices.
Result_Title: 90-hour certificate course for extension agents on behaviour change methodologies, andragogy, climate change literacy and climate smart agriculture

Project: Sustainable Tourism Enhancement Project - Phase 2: Boosting conservation and emissions reduction through tourism and technology
Description:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2 2021] 
First training on community-based ecosystems monitoring to 12 beneficiary organisations located all in the Meta Department, in the municipalities of: Cubarral, Macarena, Mesetas, Restrepo, San Martin and Villavicencio. Each organisation received a 1-hour training session which covered: 1) what is a participatory community monitoring and the process to monitor through selective components (bioindicators and abiotic indicators) and permanent plots; 2) What are conservation agreements, the process to sign one, and the associated benefits.
Result_Title: Trainings to local nature tourism organisations in community-based monitoring of ecosystems

Project: Preparing the public and financial sector for CTR: Capacity building and call to action
Description:
Development and designs of content material for the first module of the course: "Understanding and managing the climate transition". 
This module is focused on the principles of climate transition risk and the methodologies existent to assess it. Module I will have 5 sessions with a total of 12 hours of synchronic learning and 12 hours of individual work. The applied methodology will be learning by doing, in order to apply concepts and tools into the diagnosis of climate transition risk in Colombia.
The syllabus and five presentations and facilitator guidelines are developed, showing the content of each session and the methodologies implemented to quantify climate transition risks such as WTW and 2DII methodology.
Result_Title: Novel course material based on the principles of climate transition risk management and the methodologies existent to assess it

Project: Supporting livelihoods through Ecotourism Routes for Forest and Peace.
Description:
[PARTIALLY ACHIEVED] 
(1). The Marketing Working Group (MWG) of Perijá and Quinchas were established on the 10th of March 2021 and 19th of March 2021, respectively, with high engagement and commitment. The group committed to work together throughout the year to structure the marketing scheme of the destination. In Perijá, the group involves people from the 3 tourism agencies that are committed to working together. There are young people in the groups who are skilled in social media and content development. They know they need to work more in the administrative aspects of marketing. The MWG is made-up of 9 people, where 22% are women (2 in total). 
In Quinchas, since the communities are so far from each other, and many people did not know each other, there is an identified need to work harder to support them in their marketing skills, especially because they are in remote areas and not connected to Wifi. The PDP is committed to working with the communities to make sure they agree on working together to market Las Quinchas as a whole destination. The MWG in Quinchas is conformed by 19 people where 58% are women (11 women).
(2). During Q1, two participative sessions to define the yearly plans with the communities and strengthen the tourism networks were held during the first visits to Perijá and Quinchas between the 8th and 19th of March 2021. During these sessions, there was a kick-off meeting where communities remembered where they left off last year, and presented and agreed on the yearly plan, defining specific dates for the first second trimester of the year. The different groups of people were formed, according to their interest in a specific component of the touristic chain (biodiversity guidance, culinary, home-stays, marketing and admin). The communities in both regions are excited and highly engaged with the continuation of the project, and agreed with keeping the community-agreements on the benefit-sharing philosophy of the project. The initial touristic routes were also discussed and reorganized, and the communities committed to testing them before the next activity occurred. The outcome to agree the yearly plan was achieved in both regions. The attendance to each region and session was: 
Perijá: 
March 9 (La Victoria): 13 people attended (30% women). 
March 9 (Session 1 afternoon in la Jagua): 15 people attended (47% women).
March 10 (morning session): 11 people attended (45% women). 
Quinchas:
March 17th (Nazareth-Altazor communities): 21 people attended (47% women).
March 18th (Betania Quinchas): 15 people attended (53% women).
Result_Title: Series of engagements with communities to strengthen the network to develop tourism in Quinchas and Perijá

Project: Capacity building for green investment and the Green Investment Principles (GIP)
Description: PARTIALLY ACHIEVED: Q2 2021 2 day online webinar Green Finance Leadership Program (GFLP) in the context of net zero: inauguration of the GIP Central Asia Chapter. The objective of the training was to enhance environmental risk management capabilities of participants and encourage green investment amongst financial institutions in Central Asia and South East Asia through sharing of international best practice. More than 30 panelist from Kazakhstan, Mongolia, Pakistan, China, and the UK shared their insights on green investments, green taxonomies, environmental and social risk management, and biodiversity. 270 participants attended the webinar (122 male, 147 female, and 1  not recorded).
Result_Title: Green Finance Training Session for Central Asia and Southeast Asia
Implementor: Beijing Institute of Finance and Sustainability

Project: South Africa Skill share: Hydrogen Society Roadmap (ZA-001a-R)
Description:
A narrative summary of the finalised Theory of Change (ToC) and the sub-theories of change for the Hydrogen Society Roadmap (HSR) document was developed setting out the logic behind the ToCs. Advice on the structure of the HSR was provided to South Africa's Department of Science and Innovation (DSI) to better reflect the ToC’s inclusion in the HSR document. The HSR ToC was presented to the HSR Steering Group/DSI on 6 April 2021 to review and confirm the high-level ToC and the sub-ToC. The HSR ToC provides an accessible high-level overview of the objectives for a hydrogen society, including economic, social (GESI), environmental and climate objectives, in line with South Africa’s National Development Plan. It sets out the high-level outcomes which will contribute to these objectives. For each outcome the levers of change required to reach those outcomes are presented with the outputs, activities and stakeholders needed. Subsequently, DSI has incorporated the agreed theories of change and narratives into the latest version of the HSR. This has been shared with all the HSR stakeholders.
 
The preparation of the ToC was kick-started through a series of bilateral consultations with the main stakeholders. Workshops were attended by representatives of DSI, Department of Trade, Industry and Cooperation (DTIC), Department of Mineral Resources and Energy (DMRE), Department of Public Works and Infrastructure (DPWI), Department of Forestry, Fisheries and Environment (DFFE), National Treasury, SANEDI, Energy Research Centre (University of Cape Town), uYilo e-Mobility Programme, Technology Innovation Agency (TIC), North West University (HySA), Unlimited Energy, Trade and Industrial Policy Strategies (TIPS), South African Institute of International Affairs (SAIIA) and KPMG.
 
The ToC journey followed a two-step approach characterised by two workshops. During the first workshop with the Hydrogen Society Roadmap Steering Group (18 February 2021), an initial draft ToC, drawing on the bilateral stakeholder consultations, was presented to attendees for further discussion and refinement  to ensure the HSR’s aims and content were being accurately reflected. This first iteration yielded a high-level ToC prepared along with a set of sub-Theories of Change for each of the six agreed HSR outcomes – energy security, production of hydrogen, manufacture of hydrogen-related products, export of green hydrogen, decarbonisation of industry and decarbonisation of transport. The second workshop (6 April 2021) was held to review and confirm the high-level ToC and the initial sector-focused sub-Theories of Change.
Result_Title: Theory of Change (ToC) for the Hydrogen Society Roadmap (ZA-001a-R)

Project: Skill share: Colombia Climate Physical Risks and Financial Stability (COL-001a-R)
Description: A team of two green finance skill-share experts, with extensive experience of the Latin American region, supported Colombia’s Banco de la Republica (Central Bank) Financial Stability Department and economists from the Superintendencia Financiera (Financial Superintendency of Colombia) in identifying transmission channels, and then by providing recommendations towards scenario test options to show how physical climate risks affect financial stability in Colombia. The skill-share experts’ final recommendations were to incorporate information about precipitation to assess the impacts of El Nino and La Nina on financial stability variables at the national, departmental and sector (with a focus on energy) levels. This analysis will inform how different insurance and bank business models will be impacted and how their respective responses can improve the organisations' risk management practices. Additionally the results from the different climate change scenarios will be used as a tool to identify physical climate risks (impacts associated with physical damage from environmental disasters) and transition risks (risks associated with the move to a carbon-neutral economy).
Result_Title: Identify transmission channels and recommend scenario test options to show how physical climate risks affect financial stability in Colombia (COL-001a-R)

Project: Thailand Skill Share: Workshop to support Thailand to develop and adopt a cross-cutting policy for the promotion of electric vehicles on Thai roads (TH-001a-R)
Description:
The UK PACT programme mobilised two key experts (one roster expert and one representative from the UK Office for Zero Emission Vehicles (OZEV)) to deliver a presentation at a workshop on Electric Vehicle (EV) policy held on 6 May 2021. The workshop was designed to help build and strengthen the case for Thailand to adopt an EV policy and support its development by drawing on lessons learnt from the UK. The workshop was jointly convened by the British Embassy to Thailand in Bangkok, Thailand's Ministry of Energy, and the UK PACT programme led by the UK’s Department for Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy. 

The experts presented on the ‘Lessons learnt from a decade of electric mobility deployment’, and the policy implications concerning the move towards zero emission vehicles (ZEVs). This enabled the Thai government to observe the UK’s experience in formulating its policy to implement its ambitious target to phase out internal combustion engine vehicles. A workshop summary report was created which presented ten key recommendations, next steps for the Thai government, and areas of focus for future work.

The workshop had 55 attendees (including 21 females) across the following institutions: Board of Investment; Department of Alternative Energy Development and Efficiency; Electric Vehicle Association Thailand; Electricity Generation Authority Thailand; Energy Policy and Planning Office; International Affairs Division (Ministry of Energy); Ministry of Energy; Ministry of Finance; Ministry of Industry; Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment; Ministry of Transport; Office of Natural Resources and Environmental Planning; Office of the National Economic and Social Development Council; Office of Transport Planning; PTTPLC; Thailand Greenhouse gas and Management; The Federation of Thai Industries.
Result_Title: Proposed policy recommendations for Thailand's National EV Policy (based on UK best practice) (TH-001a-R)

Project: Promoting green recovery by championing the power of disclosure, transparency and UK-China collaboration
Description: Review and comparative analysis of updated environmental/climate disclosure policies by main countries/regions, including policies of HK and Mainland China, enabling policy makers to be better informed of trends and changing trends and international best practice and comparative alignment of China's climate disclosure policies.
Result_Title: Report of comparative analysis of environmental and climate disclosure policies, including HK and Mainland China.

Project: Accelerating high-quality growth in China’s Green Bond market and supporting post-COVID green economic recovery
Description:
PARTIALLY COMPLETED: 

Knowledge pieces on market development and rising issues, which facilitate better understanding of China's Green Bond Market.

Deliverables are the following:

1. Climate Bonds Launches Hydropower Criteria
2. Global GSS market update blog
3. Green finance taxonomy update
4. Monthly review for April
Result_Title: Market blog and Quarterly Newsletter

Project: Promoting green recovery by championing the power of disclosure, transparency and UK-China collaboration
Description: PARTIALLY ACHIEVED: Q1 newsletter has been completed and sent to 51 stakeholders including contacts in CSRC, MEE, CBIRC, NGOs, Companies and Financial institutions. The content of the newsletter includes recent insights of environmental disclosure, and briefly introduces the objectives, approaches and plan of CDP’s 2021 UK PACT Project.
Result_Title: Quarterly newsletter

Project: Sabah Renewable Energy Rural Electrification Road Map
Description:
[PARTIALLY ACHIEVED Q2 2021]:
Training One achieved: 17 senior staff of the primary beneficiary organisations and 15 members of the Consortium NGOs attended this on-line course over two days that introduced the mini-grid concept in the context of Sabah, with a guest lecture from one of the most successful mini-grid establishment efforts in Indonesia.  

This course was conducted on-line on 29th and 30th June 2021 with 17 senior management staff from the four primary beneficiary government agencies.  53% of course participants from the primary beneficiary agencies were women.  The course included conceptual, experiential and practical knowledge (with a virtual tour of the create space where renewable energy systems are built and taught), and a presentation by Ms. Tri Mumpuni, a leading minigrid energy developer from Indonesia.  

15 members of the consortium participated in these trainings – both as contributors and as learners.  Representatives of UK PACT were also able to introduce the initiative to the beneficiaries and to attend substantial discussions.  The obligation to undertake this training in a virtual on-line environment prevented us from being able to use a field visit to a working micro-hydro grid to achieve a different level of understanding for senior government officials.  A virtual learning environment also made it more difficult for us to understand the reactions of our participants.  We plan the next round of training to be in-person and in the field.  

Total participants on Day One were 32, and on Day Two there were 25.
Result_Title: Two trainings for senior and middle management public officials on renewable energy mini-grids

Project: Harnessing Green Finance through Climate-related Risk Management and Opportunities in Malaysia
Description:
An industry level workshop has been conducted as part of the wider JC3 Flagship Conference which was held from 23-25 June 2021. The Conference hosted a total of 6,382 attendees from 407 institutions including Board members, CEOs, Senior Management and practitioners, as well as financial institutions’ clients, investees and other value chain players. 

The workshop was structured in three different sessions:
1. The first session was delivered by Joanne Lee (Sustainable Finance Specialist, WWF) in “The role of finance” panel session on 23rd June 2021, from 10.05am - 10.50 am, with a total of 913 attendees.  Joanne was one of three panel speakers including the president of Thailand Stock Exchange, the Secretary General of Ministry of Environment and Water (Malaysia), and moderated by the CEO of Al-Rajhi Bank. The session discussed the role of finance in assisting the transition towards a low-carbon economy and how financial institutions can start to play their part and think about setting their own robust net-zero commitments.
2. The second session was delivered by Marie Gauthier (Assistant Vice President of Asia Sustainable Finance, WWF) under the asset management workshop delivering “Resilient and sustainable portfolios” on 23rd June 2021, from 2.30pm-3.00pm, with a total of 225 attendees. Marie delivered the introduction on sustainable investing, insight from WWF’s resilient and sustainable portfolios (RESPOND) assessment of asset managers, and high level recommendations for asset managers to improve portfolio resilience and alignment with a low carbon and sustainable future.
3. The third session was delivered by representatives from 2DII, Nicola Stefan Koch (Deputy Head of Retail Investment) & Constanze Bayer (Senior Analyst) under the asset management workshop on 23rd June 2021, from 4.45pm-5.15pm, with a total of 225 attendees. 2DII presented findings from their retail investment programme, what retail investors want from their non-financial goals, understanding what sustainable investment products are currently offered on the market and how “sustainable” financial products are marketed.

The JC3 event was documented and disseminated through video recordings and a rapporteur report. The recording of the sessions are published in the co-organizer youtube channel. The first session can be found here (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=szPmeTujGAk&t=11263s), and the second and third sessions can be found here (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=szPmeTujGAk&t=11263s).  The rapporteur report will be published online by the JC3 subcommitte in due course.

This output is achieved earlier than expected as the conference was conducted earlier than initially planned. WWF have completed all the works (including coordination and invitation of speakers, preparation of presentation materials, participants invitation, etc) prior to the event and prepared the workshop summary of the above sessions (with key takeaways and action points) right after. Therefore, the summary of the workshop can be reported during the first cycle of reporting in 2021 Q2.
Result_Title: Industry-wide workshop and presentation on climate related financial risk and opportunities cutting across the financial sector i.e. banking, investment and insurance.

Project: Colombia inward skillshare: Green finance
Description: Training on green finance and fintech, and sharing of the UK's experience and challenges, gained through attendance at the Green Finance Summit and meetings with BEIS, London Stock Exchange, the Investment Association, Bank of England, Climate Bonds Initiative, Aberdeen Standards Investment, Radium, Principles for Responsible Investment and Financial Conduct Authority across 5 days.
Result_Title: Meeting at the UK Green Finance Summit

Description: Training on green finance and fintech, and sharing of the UK's experience and challenges, gained through attendance at the Green Finance Summit and meetings with BEIS, London Stock Exchange, the Investment Association, Bank of England, Climate Bonds Initiative, Aberdeen Standards Investment, Radium, Principles for Responsible Investment and Financial Conduct Authority across 5 days.

Project: Advancing the UK - China’s Green Finance agenda through disclosure and demand-led capacity building for both financial firms and listed companies
Description:
An additional training session in Guangzhou with the project partner China Emissions Exchange Guangzhou (CEEX) took place. 
The session was titled 'Climate Change Risks and Opportunities and Disclosure Seminar, and the topics covered, were among others: 
- Analysis of international climate change risks and opportuinities; 
- Trends and implications of climate change disclosure; and 
- CDP questionnaires. 
The workshop had representatives from companies, financial institutions, and the government. Among others: Guangdong Province Ecological and Climate Change Exchange and Cooperation Office, Guangzhou City Huadu District Finance Bureau, British Consulate-General Guangzhou Energy and Climate Change Policy, Ping An Insurance (Group) Ltd, E-fund Management , Bank of Guangzhou, Guangzhou Agriculture and Commercial Bank, Chuangxing Bank Guangzhou Branch, Da Ye Trust, Guangzhou Huadu Fund Management, China Southern Airlines, Guangzhou Heng Yun General Energy Selling Company, Guangzhou Development Electricity Group
The decision on conducting this additional capacity building activity in Guangzhou came from the fact that Guangzhou is in an advanced stage of environmental disclosure and tackling climate change, and it was necessary to meet market demands for advanced training on the matter in the region.
Result_Title: Additional training in Guangzhou

Project: Advancing the UK - China’s Green Finance agenda through disclosure and demand-led capacity building for both financial firms and listed companies
Description:
An additional training session in Guangzhou with the project partner China Emissions Exchange Guangzhou (CEEX) took place. 
The session was titled 'Climate Change Risks and Opportunities and Disclosure Seminar, and the topics covered, were among others: 
- Analysis of international climate change risks and opportuinities; 
- Trends and implications of climate change disclosure; and 
- CDP questionnaires. 
The workshop had representatives from companies, financial institutions, and the government. Among others: Guangdong Province Ecological and Climate Change Exchange and Cooperation Office, Guangzhou City Huadu District Finance Bureau, British Consulate-General Guangzhou Energy and Climate Change Policy, Ping An Insurance (Group) Ltd, E-fund Management , Bank of Guangzhou, Guangzhou Agriculture and Commercial Bank, Chuangxing Bank Guangzhou Branch, Da Ye Trust, Guangzhou Huadu Fund Management, China Southern Airlines, Guangzhou Heng Yun General Energy Selling Company, Guangzhou Development Electricity Group
The decision on conducting this additional capacity building activity in Guangzhou came from the fact that Guangzhou is in an advanced stage of environmental disclosure and tackling climate change, and it was necessary to meet market demands for advanced training on the matter in the region.
Result_Title: Additional training in Guangzhou

Project: Advancing the UK - China’s Green Finance agenda through disclosure and demand-led capacity building for both financial firms and listed companies
Description:
A total of 452 stakeholders (for which gender was not recorded) were trained across six workshops delivered in Q1, Q2 and Q3 of 2019. One workshop in Beijing, three in Shanghai, one in Guangzhou, and one in Shenzen. 
The following topics, among others, were covered by these trainings: 
- Environmental information disclosure and requirements from regulators;
- TCFD indicators and ESG rating;
- HK Stock Exchange ESG regulations and Supply Chain Management; and
- CDP questionnaire methodology.
Each workshop had  a duration of one day. 
Some of the organisations who attended the trainings are: Lujiazui Financial City, China Institution of Capital and Financial Markets, Shanghai Zijiang International Trade Company, Huaxi Biotechnology Company, Syntao Consulting Company, Shanghai Chuangyuan Cosmestic Company, Stanley Black & Decker, Inc., ICBC.
Result_Title: Three workshops on TCFD disclosure and ESG investments

Project: Global Green Finance Leadership Programme
Description:
The 'Green Finance Capacity Building' sessions successfully held three events globally: Beijing, China in November 2018; Casablanca, Morocco in June 2019; and Nur-sultan, Kazakhstan in September 2019. 
The three events trained around 600 professionals from 60 countries around the world, mostly from emerging economies. No exact information has been provided on the number of female attendees but the project reports that gender equality is sought among the group of participants. 
These capacity building sessions were designed for key stakeholders from both public and private sectors among developing countries, with an aim to scale up green finance development in regional and national levels. During the workshops, the project provided valuable knowledge products along with best international practice, ranging from policy framework establishment, green financial products innovation, and environmental information disclosure.
All three workshops convened financial regulators, policymakers, financial institutions, and other key stakeholders for in-depth exchanges on sustainable and green finance policy roadmaps, taxonomies, policy incentives, and disclosure requirements, among others. 
Seminar 1: Beijing (China). Nov 6/7, 2018 on Policy Frameworks for Sustainable Finance. This seminar targeted participants around the world, from developed countries like France, UK, Switzerland to developing countries like Vietnam, Cambodia, Georgia, or Turkey. The seminar gave the opportunity to share China’s successful '4 pillars model' in establishing a green financial system, which includes 1) green standards, 2) incentives, 3) environmental information disclosure, and 4) green financial products. 
In 2016, China was the first country to announce its overarching green finance policy 'Guidelines for Establishing China’s Green Financial System'. Moreover, the country recently produced its national green taxonomy, and its green bond market has increased dramatically. Many countries were willing to learn from China’s green finance experience.
Seminar 2. Casablanca (Morocco). June 25/26/27, 2019 on Green Finance Seminar for Africa. This seminar mainly targeted participants from the African continent, attracting participants from Morocco, Gambia, Nigeria, Cameroon, and Ivory Coast, among others. The major topics discussed at the seminar included best practices in green banking, and green bonds market. Barriers to green finance development in Africa and options for addressing these barriers were discussed in roundtable discussions.
Sustainability issues have been discussed a lot in the region, however, the concept of green finance is still a relative new topic for African stakeholders. Therefore, the main purpose to hold this seminar was to raise the awareness on the importance of green finance, exchanging international experience, discussing the barriers and options for developing green finance in Africa. Moreover, GFLP experts were invited to help Casablanca Finance City explore the possibility in creating a regional African Green Finance Association.
Seminar 3. Nur-Sultan (Kazakhstan) September 11/12, 2019 on Green Finance Seminar for Central Asia. This seminar mainly targeted participants from Central Asia, attracting participants from Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, and Georgia, among others. The major topics discussed at the seminar included best practices in green bonds, ESG investment and the application of fintech in carbon markets. The topics covered by the workshop were: i) global initiatives in green finance; ii) green bonds and green loans, and iii) green fintech and taxonomy. 
The audience included representatives from the National Development Bank of Kazakhstan; National Bank of Kazakhstan; Government of the Kyrgyz Republic; Bank of England; and the EBRD.
As developing economies with rich natural resources, most Central Asian countries face similar environment and climate-related challenges, including extreme weather events, such as summer heatwaves and winter freezes, frequent floods and droughts, and pollution, particularly air pollution from burning coal. The seminar aimed to explore external solutions like green finance through the establishment of a market-based ecosystem.
Developing countries in general are relatively vulnerable to climate change and have weak ability in financing. Developing green finance can help them to attract international green capital, to build resilient and eco-friendly infrastructure, to better combat climate change and achieve long-term sustainable economic development eventually. Therefore, policymakers and financial professionals from developing countries are keen to learn more from international green finance practice. However, there seems to be a lack of capacity building sessions on the topic. This is the gap that GFLP is trying to fill in through these seminars. The goal is to build a knowledge sharing platform and provide opportunities for all green finance stakeholders, policymakers, supervision authorities, international investors, green project owners, to access green finance knowledge.
Result_Title: Three workshops on green finance

However, there seems to be a lack of capacity building sessions on the topic. This is the gap that GFLP is trying to fill in through these seminars. The goal is to build a knowledge sharing platform and provide opportunities for all green finance stakeholders, policymakers, supervision authorities, international investors, green project owners, to access green finance knowledge.
Result_Title: Three workshops on green finance

Project: China outward skillshare: green Asset-Backed Security (ABS) issuance
Description:
The focus of the workshop was to discuss how sustainable infrastructure could be packaged into a Debt Capital market product and focused on:
1. Institutional investor’s interest on Green ABS  (the panel showed the structure of a transaction that had taken place in Singapore late last year and this concerned the attendees that Singapore was getting a leg up on this important product)
2. Opportunities and obstacles to internationalisation of China green ABS market
3. Channels, pricing, rating, information disclosure, legal framework and other related issues
Result_Title: Workshop with potential investors and other stakeholders in the China green securitisation market

Project: Scaling up Green Finance and establishing building blocks for scalable and low carbon investment in Colombia
Description:
The two initially planned workshops were succesfully delivered in October 2019 and February 2020. 
The first workshop on Green Bonds was delivered on October 23rd 2019 in Bogota. A total of 50 people attended (26 female). Investors, issuers and stakeholders across 26 intitutions attended. 
The workshop covered the following topics: i) how climate change is affecting the world, ii) sustainability context, iii) how ESG risks become financial risks, and iv) how the financial market can be a solution. 
The second workshop on Green Bonds took place on February 14th 2020 in Medellin, and covered the same topics than the first one. A total of 48 people participated (26 female). 
Attendees belonged to the following organisations: AAGES Development Colombia SAS, Akuo Energy Colombia, Alcaldía de Medellín, Azimut Energía S.A.S, Bancolombia, Celsia S.A E.S.P, Cementos Argos S.A., Compania De Empaques S.A., Constucciones el Condor, Contreebute, Deloitte & Touche, EPM, Fabricato S.A., Grupo Argos, Grupo Nutresa SA, HMV, Idependiente, Metro de Medellin, Mineros SA, Municipio de Medellin, Pactia SAS, Portafolio Verde, PRI, Proteccion, Rentng Colombia, Semilla Cap, Sura AM, SURAMERICANA SA, TUYA, Ultraserfinco, Unal .
In addition to these two workshops, two additional training sessions were delivered on October 21st 2019 and February 28th 2020 to internal BVC staff (mainly sales people).
These two workshops serve to provide general and specific information on the connection between climate change (risks and opportunities) and the financial system. The opportunities for knowledge and experience sharing were large, given that participants came from very different institutions and sectors. The ultimate goal is that participants and their institutions shift their vision into a greener one, integrating their knowledge from the workshops.
Result_Title: Two workshops with the Colombia Stock Exchange

Project: Scaling up Green Finance and establishing building blocks for scalable and low carbon investment in Colombia
Description:
The project has successfully delivered both Green Bond Boot Camps in February 2020. 
The first Boot Camp took place on February 14th in Medellin. The bootcamp had a total of 31 male and 25 female participants.
The topics covered were green bonds basics and market overview, green bond labelling and certification, taxonomy, definitions, and criteria, and how to issue a green bond in Colombia. 
Attendees belonged to the following institutions: ODINSA, ABO Wind Renovables Colombia S.A.S., Akuo Energy Colombia, Almacenes Exito S.A., Arquitectura y Concreto, BANCOLOMBIA, BTG Pactual, Camara de Comercio de Medellin, Celsia, Cementos Argos, Compania DE Empaues, Cueros Velez, Deloitte & Touche, Empresas Publicas de Medellin- EPM, Fabricato, FINAGRO, Grupo Nutresa S.A., Grupo Renovatio, Hybrytec Power, Independiente- Consultor, ISA, Isagen SA, Metro de Medelliln, Offcors, Pactia, Productores Faminia S.A., Proteccion, Seguros Sura Colombia, Semilla Cap, Sura Investment Management, SURAMERICANA S.A.
The second Booth Camp was delivered on February 17th 2020 in Bogotá. This bootcamp had a total of 45 male and 50 female participants. The topics covered were the same than the ones in the first Boot Camp. 
Attendees belonged to the following institutions: Acueducto de Bogotá, AES Colombia, Agencia Nacional de Ingeniería, Alpina S.A., Arrocera la Esmeralda, Asobancaria, Asobolsa - Asociación de Comisionistas de Bolsa de Colombia, Asofondos, Banca Corficolombia, Banco Agrario, Banco de Bogotá, Banco de Occidente, Banco Finandina, Banco Pichincha, Banco Popular, Carbones Andinos Caso sostenible, Constructora Jaramillo Mora, Corficolombiana, CORPORACION CIINAS, CORREDORES DAVIVIENDA, DIESTRO, DNP, Ecopetrol, EDF Renouvelables, Emgesa S.A. E.S.P., Enel Green Power Colombia S.A.S. E.S.P., Enerfín., ETB, Financiera de Desarrollo Nacional FDNGEB, Gobernación de Cundinamarca, Grupo Aval, Grupo Energía de Bogotá, IFC, Inverlink, Itaú, ITAU COMISIONISTA DE BOLSA, ITAU CORPBANCA COLOMBIA, Keralty, KMPG, Manuelita, NEOEN, Optima Consultores, Óptima Consultores, Organización Terpel S.A., PEI, Política, Promigas S.A. E.S.P., Rayo Energía, Refeel, Scotiabank Colpatria, Semana, SFC, Siembra Más (Alcaldía de Barranquilla), Solar Pack, Terracol, Titularizadora Colombiana S.A., Transmilenio, ULTRASERFINCO, Valores Bancolombia.
These Boot Camps laid the foundations of what a green bond is, how to issue it, and what its operating mechanism is. They also served to analyse issues such as global developments to date, market dynamics, the role of different financial institutions, pricing, internationally approved standards and definitions, potential benefits of the issuance of green bonds, and CBI taxonomy and methodology. The goal was to drive the development of the financial market and be part of the rapid growth of the global green bond market.
Result_Title: Two training sessions (‘Boot Camps’) to ensure knowledge transfer and enduring capacity

The second Booth Camp was delivered on February 17th 2020 in Bogotá. This bootcamp had a total of 45 male and 50 female participants. The topics covered were the same than the ones in the first Boot Camp. 
Attendees belonged to the following institutions: Acueducto de Bogotá, AES Colombia, Agencia Nacional de Ingeniería, Alpina S.A., Arrocera la Esmeralda, Asobancaria, Asobolsa - Asociación de Comisionistas de Bolsa de Colombia, Asofondos, Banca Corficolombia, Banco Agrario, Banco de Bogotá, Banco de Occidente, Banco Finandina, Banco Pichincha, Banco Popular, Carbones Andinos Caso sostenible, Constructora Jaramillo Mora, Corficolombiana, CORPORACION CIINAS, CORREDORES DAVIVIENDA, DIESTRO, DNP, Ecopetrol, EDF Renouvelables, Emgesa S.A. E.S.P., Enel Green Power Colombia S.A.S. E.S.P., Enerfín., ETB, Financiera de Desarrollo Nacional FDNGEB, Gobernación de Cundinamarca, Grupo Aval, Grupo Energía de Bogotá, IFC, Inverlink, Itaú, ITAU COMISIONISTA DE BOLSA, ITAU CORPBANCA COLOMBIA, Keralty, KMPG, Manuelita, NEOEN, Optima Consultores, Óptima Consultores, Organización Terpel S.A., PEI, Política, Promigas S.A. E.S.P., Rayo Energía, Refeel, Scotiabank Colpatria, Semana, SFC, Siembra Más (Alcaldía de Barranquilla), Solar Pack, Terracol, Titularizadora Colombiana S.A., Transmilenio, ULTRASERFINCO, Valores Bancolombia.
These Boot Camps laid the foundations of what a green bond is, how to issue it, and what its operating mechanism is. They also served to analyse issues such as global developments to date, market dynamics, the role of different financial institutions, pricing, internationally approved standards and definitions, potential benefits of the issuance of green bonds, and CBI taxonomy and methodology. The goal was to drive the development of the financial market and be part of the rapid growth of the global green bond market.
Result_Title: Two training sessions (‘Boot Camps’) to ensure knowledge transfer and enduring capacity

Project: Colombia Climate Finance Accelerator Follow-Up
Description:
The kick-off workshop took place on November 19th, 2019, during the Colombian Climate Finance Event hosted by the Department of National Planning. The workshop had a duration of half a day and was attended by 50 people from the national government, private sector, international and local banks (Bancolombia, Bancoldex, BNP Paribas, Banco Agrario), and non-profit organizations. 
The first half of the workshop featured presentations on Colombia’s national climate goals, the CFA initiative process, and the concept of blended finance and the climate finance supply chain. In particular, this part of the workshop featured presentations from Carolina Diaz, the Deputy Director for Risk Management and Climate Change at DNP, who presented on Colombia’s national climate goals; from Marie-Justine Labelle, on behalf of PwC, on blended finance; and from several representatives of financial institutions which provided examples of climate projects which have been funded with blended mechanisms. 
The second half of the workshop consisted in small group discussions organized by sector and facilitated by members of the CFA consortium and financial experts. Each group discussed financing challenges and opportunities unique to their sector. 
Through these discussions, the consortium identified a short-list of 16 projects suitable for the CFA.  In the weeks which followed the kick-off workshop, the project continued in communication with the short-listed organisations and finally selected 10 of them to receive full support.  
The kick-off workshop provided an opportunity to educate a broader group of project developers on blended finance. We were also able to increase the visibility of the CFA program and the work of UK PACT in Colombia, as the kick-off was part of a national event attended by many stakeholders. The breakout innovation sessions allowed members of the CFA consortium to better understand the status of projects submitted in the open call and more generally the common challenges across the sectors. This informed the design of the coaching webinars and the distribution of the projects for the final workshop.
Result_Title: Two-day kick-off workshop

Project: Colombia Climate Finance Accelerator Follow-Up
Description:
A three-day final CFA workshop was conducted in Bogota between 4th and 6th March 2020. The number of attendees has not been confirmed. 
This final workshop was the result of all the coaching work conducted between November 2019 and February 2020 with the 10 selected projects. These participated in four brief coaching webinars whose final objective was to improve the technical capacities of the project personnel in preparing project quality term sheets and prepare them for this final workshop. Each coaching session focused on different sections of the term sheet: due diligence, financial details, risks, and final presentation.  
This final workshop consisted in two public sessions and closed ‘deep dive’ sessions. Regarding the public sessions, the workshop secured  the participation of four strategic offices of the Colombian national government: Department of National Planning, Ministry of Treasury and Public Credit, Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development, and Colombia Productiva in the Ministry of Commerce, and Industry and Tourism.  With respect to the deep dive sessions, at least two consortium representatives attended each of the deep dive groups. In these sessions project developers were paired with financial institutions, to make the discussions more productive. 
Banco Agrario and private equity houses participated in these sessions. 
After the workshop, both partner banks and project sponsors reported that the experience was meaningful, and the latter also considered that the sessions have helped them understand and improve their financial structures and presentations to potential financial institutions. 
This training workshop was intended to improve the bankability of the participating projects and the capacity of the project proponents to access innovative finance, such as blended finance. The 2-3 hour sessions for each project with financial experts were of utmost importance because it allowed for deep analysis of the project financial structure and for discussion amongst the financial experts about the merits of the project and the potential financing mechanisms that might be applicable. The workshop successfully provided specific and relevant feedback for each participating project and all project proponents incorporated the feedback into their final presentations in the public closing session. Additionally, the project developers noted that they had learned how to present their projects in a clearer way and tailor their presentations to their audience. This will prepare them to pitch their projects more effectively to financial institutions. It was important to have closed, in-person sessions because the small groups and private environment enabled project proponents to disclose confidential details of their projects that allowed the financial experts to better assess which financial structure or mechanisms would be best suited to that project.
Result_Title: Three-day CFA workshop

Project: Unlocking the Colombian government fund FENOGE to provide energy access whilst reducing greenhouse gas emissions ​
Description:
A capacity-building workshop was delivered in Bogotá on July 12th, 2019.
A total of 40 participants from public and private sector attended the training, including: FENOGE, UPME, IPSE, CREG, FINDETER, CECIL and Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency project developers. 
The focus of the training was on how to use the tools and frameworks developed by CT and reviewed by FENOGE. The training also created a space to share learnings from other relevant energy access and energy efficiency projects carried out by the Carbon Trust in other relevant countries. 
During the training, participants were also given the opportunity to provide feedback on the tools and materials. In particular, feedback received from UPME and FINDETER was incorporated into the final version of the tools.
Result_Title: Capacity building on the use of tools

The focus of the training was on how to use the tools and frameworks developed by CT and reviewed by FENOGE. The training also created a space to share learnings from other relevant energy access and energy efficiency projects carried out by the Carbon Trust in other relevant countries. 
During the training, participants were also given the opportunity to provide feedback on the tools and materials. In particular, feedback received from UPME and FINDETER was incorporated into the final version of the tools.
Result_Title: Capacity building on the use of tools

Project: Mexico inward skillshare: Carbon budgets and climate strategy
Description:
Training conducted through meetings with academics (UCL) government officials (BEIS Carbon Markets team, Committee on Climate Change) and other stakeholders (Grantham Institute, Green Alliance). 
Meetings held over 3.5 days but not everyone attended, resulting in 17.5 person-days of training. 
The skill-share involved the implementors of the '2030 Decarbonisation Pathways' bilateral project and was undertaken to support the project's implementation.
Result_Title: Transfer knowledge from UK experts to achieve political consensus in carbon budgets

Project: Scaling up Green Finance and establishing building blocks for scalable and low carbon investment in Colombia
Description:
A webinar disseminating lessons learned from Pacific Alliance members countries to promote the green bond market in Colombia was delivered on May 8th, 2020. 
The webinar presented two study cases from the Pacific Alliance, detailing advantages and difficulties undergone for the issuance of green bonds. FIRA from Mexico (with a certified green bond) and Bancoldex from Colombia (first issuer of a green bond in the public market) were invited as international speakers to present their experience as issuers. They explained why they chose a green bond, what projects and assets they financed, how was their structuring and emission process, who invested in it, and some of thee lessons learned throughout the process, challenges and recommendations. 
Moreover, CBI's market expert from London was invited to explain the current state of the green financial market in Latin America and how he perceived the possibility of issuing green bonds in the current situation. The webinar generated a lot of interest from participants, and there were more than 30 questions posed at the end. 
The webinar had a total of 343 participants. 181 participants were female and 162 participants were male.
Result_Title: Webinar on regional case studies
